headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Limited Brands Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Ms. Amie Preston, Vice President In
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Limited Brands Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Ms. Amie Preston, Vice President Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Christie. Good morning, everyone and welcome to the Limited Brands Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the period ending Saturday, January 30, 2010. As a matter of formality, I need to remind you that any forward-looking statements we may
componenttext: Thanks, Christie. Good morning, everyone and welcome to the Limited Brands Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the period ending Saturday, January 30, 2010. As a matter of formality, I need to remind you that any forward-looking statements we may make today are subject to our Safe Harbor statements found in our SEC filings. Our fourth quarter earnings release and related financial information, including any non-GAAP or adjusted financial reconciliation tables, are available on our website, www.limitedbrands.com.This call is being taped and can be replayed by dialing 1-866-NEWS-LTD. You can also listen to an audio replay from our website.Martyn Redgrave, EVP and Chief Administrative Officer; Stuart Burgdoerfer, EVP and Chief Financial Officer; Sharen Turney, CEO of Victoria's Secret; and Diane Neal, CEO of Bath & Body Works are all joining us today. After our prepared comments, we will be available to take your questions for as long as time permits. So that we can speak with as many callers as possible, please limit yourself to one question. Thanks, and now I'll turn the call over to Martyn Redgrave.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Amie, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start by saying that we're very pleased with our performance in the fourth quarter. The strength of our assortments combined with disciplined inventory and expense management enabled us to significantl
componenttext: Thanks, Amie, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start by saying that we're very pleased with our performance in the fourth quarter. The strength of our assortments combined with disciplined inventory and expense management enabled us to significantly reduce our promotional activity. On an adjusted basis, our gross margin rate increased 650 basis points in the quarter. Operating income dollars increased 50%, and the operating income rate increased by 610 basis points.Our adjusted earnings per share, as I know you've read, increased 49% to $1.01. This strong performance was the result of our intense focus on execution, staying close to our customers and increasing speed and agility. As we enter 2010, we recognize that the environment remains uncertain and challenging. Accordingly, as Stuart will explain in more detail in a minute, we will continue to manage inventory, expenses and capital very conservatively.We will also continue to drive the business with an overriding focus on disciplined execution of retail fundamentals. Improving our ability to react with speed and agility to maximize our sales and profit opportunities is a critical priority. In addition, with the last phase of our retail operations platform technology systems implemented last year, we will begin to capitalize on the benefits at Victoria's Secret and further leverage the benefits we are realizing at BBW.Our entire organization is aligned and focused on these key imperatives. And while we make considerable projects, we see many more opportunities to improve in many areas. Our number one priority continues to be improving the results of our core U.S. businesses. We improved our full year operating margins by 200 basis points to 9.9% this year and we remain very focused on achieving our goal of 15%.Now before I turn it over to Stuart, I'd like to provide you with an update on our International businesses beginning with La Senza business. As we announced in the last quarter's call, we completed the closure of the La Senza Girl free standing stores in the fourth quarter. La Senza Girl has had a negative impact on La Senza's financial performance and was not aligned with our overall strategic focus on lingerie and personal care and beauty. The costs and charges related to this closure totaled roughly $13 million in the fourth quarter. Also in the fourth quarter, La Senza comps were down 2% in the core Lingerie business. Total La Senza comps, which include La Senza Girl, were down 4%.Then excluding the costs of the closure of La Senza Girl business, the gross margin rate increased significantly, driven by a significant increase in the merchandised margin rate, which was benefited by a favorable currency impact compared to last year as well as an improved assortment. As we've mentioned previously, La Senza purchases its merchandise in U.S. dollars. Also despite the negative comp, SG&A expense leveraged. Excluding the cost related to the closure of the La Senza Girl business, operating income dollar and rate increased.For the full year, La Senza comps in the core Lingerie business declined 6%, and the total business, including La Senza Girl, declined 8%. Total sales were $423.5 million excluding costs related to the closure of La Senza Girl. Operating income dollars and rate increased over last year.As we mentioned on the last call, President Joanne Nemeroff and her team are testing changes in the marketing and store layout, as well as more focused assortment. We saw a very strong results from these test stores in the fourth quarter. And as a result, we will be rolling these changes out to more stores in the spring. So on balance, we are actively engaged in the strategy to turn this business around, and we're confident that we will see improvement in 2010.Turning to our other businesses in Canada, we ended the year with 31 Bath & Body Works stores and four Pink stores. We continue to be very pleased with the performance of these new stores. In 2010, we will open four Canadian Victoria's Secret stores in the West Edmonton Mall and the Toronto area. In addition, we plan to open five more Pink stores and 30 to 35 more Bath & Body Works stores across the country.We also ended the year with seven stores operating under the new travel and tourism retail model. You may remember from our Update Meeting that these are small Victoria's Secret stores focused on beauty and Victoria's Secret brand and accessories. The stores are approximately 1,000 square feet in size and are operated by partners under our wholesale model. And they are principally located in airports and tourist destinations. These stores continue to deliver very strong results, with sales productivity levels in the thousands per square foot.In 2010, we will continue to work on refining and improving the assortment offering in these stores and make sure that we have a robust infrastructure to support further growth. We plan to open another 10 to 15 stores this year. So in summary, we're building our existing base of profitable sales outside of the United States. With our expansion plans in Canada and the early success we are seeing and other initiatives, we believe we are just beginning to exploit the full potential of our brands internationally. Thanks, and I'll now turn it over to Stuart.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Martyn, and good morning, everybody. So turning to our fourth quarter performance, our adjusted earnings per share increased 49% to $1.01 per share versus $0.68 last year. Our reported 2009 results was $1.08 per share versus $0.05 last year. Both
componenttext: Thanks, Martyn, and good morning, everybody. So turning to our fourth quarter performance, our adjusted earnings per share increased 49% to $1.01 per share versus $0.68 last year. Our reported 2009 results was $1.08 per share versus $0.05 last year. Both of these and last year's reported results include significant items as detailed in our press release. I won't repeat last year's items, but this year's fourth quarter reported results included a tax benefit of $23 million or $0.07 per share, primarily related to the reorganization of certain foreign subsidiaries.Our results discussed on this call excludes the insignificant items in both years. Our fourth quarter earnings per share of $1.01 significantly exceeded our beginning of the quarter expectation of $0.71 to $0.86 per share. This upside was driven by better comps and merchandising margin results. To take you through the fourth quarter results in more detail, net sales were $3.063 billion versus $2.991 billion last year and comps increased 1%. The gross margin rate increased 650 basis points to 40.8%, primarily driven by significant increases in the merchandised margin rate at all of our businesses. Volume and occupancy expenses leveraged as a percentage of sales.SG&A dollars increased by $26.1 million or 5% and the SG&A rate increased by 30 basis points, primarily driven by higher incentive compensation payouts this year, as last year's payout were essentially zero. Total operating income increased $194.8 million or 50% and 610 basis points as a percent of sales to $585.5 million or 19.1% of sales. By segment, the Victoria's Secret segment increased by $97.6 million or 520 basis points as a percent of sales to $311 million or 17.3% of sales. Bath & Body Works increased by $85.1 million or 820 basis points as a percent of sales to $294.6 million or 29.2% of sales. And the other segment operating loss declined by $12.1 million to $20 million. Total non-operating expenses increased by $6.2 million, driven by incremental interest expense that was partially offset by the recognition of our 25% interest in expressive fourth quarter net income. For the full year 2009, excluding the significant items described in our press release, earnings per share increased 17% to $1.23 versus $1.05 last year. Net sales were $8.632 billion versus $9.043 billion last year, and comps decreased 4%.The gross margin rate increased 190 basis points to 35.1%, driven by a significant increase in the merchandised margin rate that was slightly offset by buying and occupancy deleverage. SG&A dollars decreased by $119 million or 5% and despite the negative comp, the SG&A rate improved by 20 basis points, driven by our cost-reduction efforts, partially offset by a higher incentive compensation expense for the fall season.Total operating income increased $140.7 million or 20% to $858.3 million, and our operating income rate improved by 200 basis points to 9.9%. By segment, the Victoria's Secret segment decreased by $41.3 million or 20 basis points as a percent of sales to $578.5 million, 10.9% of sales. Bath & Body Works increased by $142.7 million or 600 basis points as a percent of sales to $358.2 million or 15% of sales. And the other segment operating loss declined by $39.3 million to $78.5 million.I know there has been some interest in the drivers of results in the other segment, but I would like to take some time to provide some additional clarity. The other segment consist of our sourcing function, mass and beauty avenues, the Henri Bendel business, corporate overhead and all of our international operations, except La Senza, which is included in the Victoria's Secret segment. For the full year, roughly 85% of other segment revenue consist of mass sales to third-party retailers. Total other segment revenue for the year declined by $121.8 million or 11% to $943 million. This decline was driven by an 18% decline in mass revenue, primarily due to contractual reductions in the Express and Limited Stores businesses. The mass revenue decline was partially offset by an increase in revenue from our international operations, particularly BBW Canada. The other segment operating loss is driven by corporate overhead expense and a loss from our Henri Bendel business, which is partially offset by operating income from mass and our International business. The decline in the 2009 other segment operating loss was driven by a reduction in corporate overhead resulting from our cost-reduction efforts and also benefited from increased income from our international operations. So now moving down the income statement below operating income, total non-operating expenses for the year increased by $68.8 million, driven by incremental interest expense and a reduction in interest income that was partially offset by improved performance at Express. Turning to the balance sheet, retail inventories per square footage cost ended the year down 9% versus last year and down 16% on a two-year basis. We reduced our overall debt balance by $174 million this year, $158 million of which was a prepayment of our term loan in the fourth quarter. We ended the year with $2.7 billion in total debt and $1.8 billion in cash.Free cash flow in 2009 was $972 million, a record year. 2009 capital expenditures were $202 million versus $479 million last year, and depreciation and amortization was $357 million. So now turning to the first quarter of 2010, we're forecasting earnings per share between $0.05 and $0.10. This forecast reflects a comp increase of 2% to 4%, between 2% and 4%, which includes our updated February comp guidance of high single to low double digits. We anticipate that the gross margin rate will be up to last year, driven by an improvement in the merchandise margin rate. And we expect the SG&A rate to be roughly flat.We are currently in discussions to amend our bank facility with the objective of providing additional flexibility around restricted payments. We will announce any new terms and their impact when we come to an agreement. We expect interest expense of approximately $61 million in the first quarter, which includes an estimated $10 million in one-time incremental expense related to the anticipated payoff of the remaining $200 million under our term loan and the amendment of our revolver. We expect roughly $7 million in other income, principally representing our share of Express and Limited Stores income.Before any discrete items, our tax rate will be approximately 38%, and weighted average shares will approximate 330 million in the first quarter. We expect to end the first quarter with inventory per square foot down in the high single-digit range.Moving to the full year, we are projecting a comp result of flat to low single-digit positive. Full year gross margins will be up to last year, primarily driven by improvement in merchandise margin rate. We expect the full year SG&A expense rate to be roughly flat to last year. We expect full year interest expense of about $215 million, down about $25 million from last year, as a result of our reduction in debt in 2009 and the anticipated repayment of our term loan this year.We are projecting total other income, including interest income, of roughly $40 million, approximately $20 million above last year driven by increased income from Express and Limited Stores. This estimate assumes the continuation of the positive business trends in these businesses, and that we will continue to account for our ownership in Express under the equity method of accounting in 2010. Depending on our ownership percentage in Express subsequent to their IPO and certain other factors, our accounting could change, especially if we would no longer be recognizing income from this investment.So assuming all these inputs, we expect earnings per share for the full year 2010 to be between $1.40 and $1.60 per share. We continue to aggressively manage capital expenditures. We are projecting 2010 CapEx between $250 million and $300 million, with roughly 70% of the spending on real estate and stores.We plan to open roughly 50 stores this year mostly in Canada and close roughly 75 stores. We'll end the year with total square foot roughly flat to last year. The details of our 2010 store plan are included in the supplemental financial information package on our website. Our remaining CapEx spending, as you know relates, to technology, distribution centers and home office projects.Turning to liquidity, we expect free cash flow in 2010 between $500 million and $600 million. Our free cash flow and cash position, along with the additional availability under our revolving credit facility result in a very strong liquidity, which is more than sufficient to fund our working capital, capital expenditures, dividend and any other foreseeable need. So thanks, and now I'll turn this discussion over to Sharen.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stuart, and good morning, everyone. I will begin my remarks this morning with a review of fourth quarter performance, then I'll address how we are positioned heading into the first quarter.We are pleased with our fourth quarter results, and I a
componenttext: Thank you, Stuart, and good morning, everyone. I will begin my remarks this morning with a review of fourth quarter performance, then I'll address how we are positioned heading into the first quarter.We are pleased with our fourth quarter results, and I am particularly encouraged by how we achieved them with strong execution of the fundamental and responding to the customer with speed and agility. As a result, performance was consistently positive throughout the brand. To that point, we delivered good results in both channels, Bras our best set category and across virtually all other categories.Now I will address fourth quarter results for the stores channel. Victoria's Secret stores fourth quarter comp was flat to last year, and total sales were up 1% to $1.2 billion. Our comp results improved steadily throughout the year, as we corrected spring assortment issues and focused on execution. Comps improved from negative 11 in the spring to down four in the third quarter and flat in the fourth quarter.Our results were driven by straight in our Bra assortment and supported by improved results in the Panty category. The Miraculous Bra delivered strong results both at large and throughout the quarter. Combined with continued growth in other push-up styles and tease bras, we drove broad category growth at significantly improved margin rates. This was in part due to improved agility, including chasing an additional 400,000 units in the Miraculous Bra, which contributed to fourth quarter sales.Panties were also up to last year. Customers responded well to our assortment and we taste [ph] into winner, including bright colors and panties that match bras. We presented a more focused and fashion-like [ph] assortment this holiday, which exceeded our expectation and delivered significantly higher margin dollars over last year.In Pink apparel, lace bottoms and tops in our collegiate program were strong performance. Beauty sales, although down to last year, significantly exceeded our expectation at higher margin rate. A balance of conservative inventory positioning, coupled with a strong gift set strategy, allowed us to hold ticket prices throughout holiday and achieve strong regular price sell-through. Improvement in field execution created an improved customer experience and drove record conversion in the fourth quarter. This more than offset declines in traffic in 2009 against the highly promotional 2008.The merchandise margin rate was up significantly in the quarter. A strong assortment, well-controlled inventory and chasing key items enabled us to reduce promotion and increase full price selling. Operating income dollars and rate at Victoria's Secret stores were both up significantly to last year.Turning to performance at Direct, sales in the quarter were up 3% to last year, we've significantly improved results in several key categories by driving more units, innovation and fashion. For example, in sleepwear, we added more colors, brands[ph] and set, which drove Holiday business up double digit and higher margin. Merchandise margin rate was up significantly to last year, driven by an improved assortment, higher inventory and fewer promotion. Operating income dollars and rate were both up significantly to last year.For the full year, Victoria's Secret stores sales was $3.5 billion, and comps declined 6%. The gross margin rate decline, driven by buying and occupancy expense deleverage and a slight decline in the merchandise margin rate. We were able to leverage SG&A expense on a negative comp due to our expense reduction efforts. Operating income dollars declined by about 5%, and the operating income rate decreased slightly. At the Direct business, full year sales increased 9% to $1.4 billion. The gross margin rate increased, primarily driven by an increase in the merchandise margin rate. SG&A expense deleverage on the sales decline, operating income dollars decreased slightly and the operating income rate increased by about 100 basis points.Looking ahead to the first quarter, we are continuing to plan conservatively in light of the uncertain environment. We will manage inventory and expenses cautiously and rely on increased open to buy and sourcing agility to realize upside. We feel good about how the business is positioned compared to how we began in 2009. Today, inventory and expenses are well-controlled. Last year, we came out of the fourth quarter with too much inventory as a result of the challenging holiday environment. Today, we have a much stronger assortment, with more depth behind key items, stronger fashion and more color going into this year.We have reoriented the organization to speed as a core cultural value. We have more open to buy, and we are position to gain upside by quickly chasing into winning style. And we have an excellent lineup of new product introductions in the first quarter. Throughout the quarter, we will continue to drive momentum with our broad launches, we will use early reads of customer responses to upside. Our Wild At Heart Valentine's Day Theme ended last week and may we move into a spring focused core set with an emphasis on push-up bra. In March, we will build on the success of The Body by Victoria Collection and introduce three new styles and push-up, a racerback demi and a strapless convertible.In April, we will introduce a bra collection targeting a customer to prefer little padding and a lighter bra. We will also continue to build on the Pink Bra business throughout spring. In Panties, we will introduce more patterns and colors that match bras, and we will continue to focus on key items that like the lacy program can color multiply.In Beauty, we will launch several new fragrances including three new Pink fragrances. We will focus on gift giving at Mother's Day. In the Direct channel, we will leverage the Bra, Panty and Pink, and Beauty strategies that I just mentioned. And then build on those businesses with fashion and innovation in swim, dresses and small tops.In closing, we are pleased with our progress. But far from satisfied, we will continue to focus on execution with discipline, simplicity and speed. And of course, staying close to our customer we will continue to be the priority. So we can maximize ourselves and profitability in the spring. Thanks, and now I will turn it over to Diane.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sharen and good morning. At Bath & Body Works, we're encouraged by the results of the fourth quarter. We were able to deliver sales and income growth despite operating in a difficult retail environment. We have continued to focus on our three k
componenttext: Thank you, Sharen and good morning. At Bath & Body Works, we're encouraged by the results of the fourth quarter. We were able to deliver sales and income growth despite operating in a difficult retail environment. We have continued to focus on our three key categories: Our Signature Collection product line, the Anti-Bacterial business and our Home Fragrance Assortment, which all continue to deliver improved results versus last year.Signature Collection was driven by the new Twilight Woods Fragrance, which launched at the end of the third quarter. Twilight Woods exceeded our expectations as it's one of our most successful fragrance launches in the company history. The Anti-Bac business posted gains over last year, driven by growth in both of our soap and hand sanitizer category. In January, we restaged our Anti-Bac Collection including packaging, new formulas and new forms. We are pleased with the performance of the restage line, which continued on a strong growth trajectory. Our Home Fragrance sales throughout the last year, driven by our strong candle performance.Focusing on the three key categories helped us drive positive results in the fourth quarter, including delivering a Black Friday that was the biggest sales day ever for Bath & Body Works, selling our seasonal collections at full price throughout Christmas, increasing conversion significantly versus last year helping to partially offset traffic declines, while customers also spent more for transaction versus last year.So with that backdrop, let me take you through the financial results for the quarter. Bath & Body Works fourth quarter comps were up 2%. Total sales for the quarter were $1 billion, which is up 1% or $10 million versus last year. For the quarter, our operating income was $295 million, which was up $85 million or 41% for the fourth quarter of last year. Operating income was driven by the positive sales comp, improvements in merchandise margin rate and expense decreases in buying and occupancy. Buying and occupancy leveraged in the fourth quarter.Operating income as a percentage of the sales was 29% in the quarter, which was up significantly to last year, driven by improvement in the gross margin rate. Improvement in gross margin rate was driven by the merchandise margin rate, which is up significantly versus last year, driven by our cost-reduction efforts and better inventory management. Our focus on inventory management allows to be less promotional versus last year, including a semi-annual sales that was eight days shorter. The active management of inventory also allowed us to finish the quarter with inventory levels down to last year. This is our 11th consecutive quarter with inventories down year over year, while our in-stock positions continue to improve. For fiscal 2009, operating income was $358 million, which is up $143 million or 66% versus last year. Operating income as a percentage of sales was 15%, which is up 600 basis points from last year. The operating income performance was driven by improvements in merchandise margin rate and expense reductions in buying and occupancy and SG&A.The BBW Direct channel delivered strong growth, and we continue to view the Direct channel as both the revenue generator and the marketing vehicle for our brand. So with that in mind, I would like to give you a preview of what our customers can expect in the first quarter of 2010 and beyond as our newness is up significantly to last year. Signature Collection will continue to have newness later [ph] and throughout the spring. In February, we launched P.S. I love You Too, which is the new fragrance in our P.S. I love You franchise the successfully launched last fall. Two new fragrances Sweet Pea Forever & Moonlight Magic launched on February 19, along with all new graphics for two of our top fragrances, Sweet Pea & Moonlight Path. We will be also launching the new Orange [ph] Sapphire fragrance in March and a collection of Summer Vanilla Fragrances in April. Our Signature Collection Body Lotion, which is our largest form will launch in April in all new improved formula. The Home Fragrance Assortment will have a new Fragrance Collection, the Perfect Escape and Fresh Kit Collection launching a candle and diffuser.We're also increasing fragrance offerings on our order elimination category and testing new innovative forms in the passive diffuser area. For the Anti-Bacterial business, we are planning to leverage the recently restaged packaging, improved formulas and forms to increase our already dominant position in the Anti-Bacterial Hand Soap and Sanitizer market. We will also launch new fragrances in soap and sanitizers, as well as kitchen odor elimination collection. In addition to our focus on product and fragrance launches, we will continue to manage expenses and inventory very conservatively.We are cautiously optimistic about the first quarter, but are excited about our spring assortment and the visual appeal of our shop. Offering newness, responding to business trends and touching new products and promotional strategies to drive traffic and gain share. And with that, I'll turn the discussion back over to Amie.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Diane. That concludes our prepared remarks and at this time, we'll be happy to take any questions you might have. Again just a reminder, please try to limit yourself to one question. So that we can get to as many people as possible and you can alw
componenttext: Thanks, Diane. That concludes our prepared remarks and at this time, we'll be happy to take any questions you might have. Again just a reminder, please try to limit yourself to one question. So that we can get to as many people as possible and you can always get back into the queue. Thanks, and I'll turn it over to Christie.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Kimberly Greenberger from Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Kimberly Greenberger from Citi.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I noticed that you're looking at closing some stores this year, it looks like about 76 stores are slated for closure. Stuart, could you just remind us -- I think you have very, very few stores that are not free cash flow positive on a four wall basis. If
componenttext: I noticed that you're looking at closing some stores this year, it looks like about 76 stores are slated for closure. Stuart, could you just remind us -- I think you have very, very few stores that are not free cash flow positive on a four wall basis. If you could just update us on those performance metrics, and what was it that led you to take another look at your fleet with an eye towards those closures?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with respect to store closures, two or three things that I want to comment on, and also in answer to your question, one is that after tax cash flow statistics for our fleet actually improved from the last time we updated on reflecting the Q4 resu
componenttext: Sure. So with respect to store closures, two or three things that I want to comment on, and also in answer to your question, one is that after tax cash flow statistics for our fleet actually improved from the last time we updated on reflecting the Q4 results. So we're now at 99% of our stores with positive after-tax cash flow. So I think your curiosity is why then would you guys will be closing 75 stores. So with respect to that, the thing I really want to convey is that is a very conservative estimate. I think it's likely that number that we actually close could be materially less than that, and stay in the range of 40 or 50 actual stores. As you know and the fleet of 3,000 stores you're always opening and closing some stores. And again, it's a conservative view and in part reflects the fact that some malls are vulnerable and becoming marginal. So again, I think the 75 is a very conservative number, and the health of our fleet remains very strong with the after-tax cash flow results improving after the strong fourth quarter that we're in.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I just follow-up on one thing that you mentioned earlier, the renegotiating, it sounds like you're talking to your banks right now to loosen up some of the restrictions on cash deployment, what would be your hope in terms of what you might do with tha
componenttext: Can I just follow-up on one thing that you mentioned earlier, the renegotiating, it sounds like you're talking to your banks right now to loosen up some of the restrictions on cash deployment, what would be your hope in terms of what you might do with that cash if in fact you're able to get those labors?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Three or four overall points on that, general subject. The first is that we have been managing as we've been talking about the business pretty conservatively and got to the $900 million plus in free cash flow in the $1.8 billion of ending cash. So w
componenttext: Sure. Three or four overall points on that, general subject. The first is that we have been managing as we've been talking about the business pretty conservatively and got to the $900 million plus in free cash flow in the $1.8 billion of ending cash. So we are in the middle of discussions with our bank group, and we have a great bank group. And those discussions are aimed at amending that facility to reduce the limits on restricted payments. And once we get through that process as we periodically do and in consultation with our Board, we'll evaluate what's the best uses for excess cash, and we've accumulated a lot of cash this year, and we'll evaluate that in due course in consultation with our Board.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michelle Tan from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michelle Tan from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question, as we look at the sales you're talking to for February, they're very strong yet it really seems like February should be the toughest month of the quarter just given the snowstorms and everything that's happened. What's driving the strength yo
componenttext: My question, as we look at the sales you're talking to for February, they're very strong yet it really seems like February should be the toughest month of the quarter just given the snowstorms and everything that's happened. What's driving the strength you're seeing in February? And I guess, why don't you see that continuing through the first quarter based on your guidance?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Michelle I think we'll go to Stuart for the comment about the first quarter, but then we'll go to Sharen and Diane maybe for some comments about February specifically.
componenttext: So Michelle I think we'll go to Stuart for the comment about the first quarter, but then we'll go to Sharen and Diane maybe for some comments about February specifically.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in terms of February as we're indicating, we're expecting high-single to low double-digit result. But then as we think about the quarter, we consider four or five other things. The first is that the Q4 comp result was a plus one. And if we will look ba
componenttext: So in terms of February as we're indicating, we're expecting high-single to low double-digit result. But then as we think about the quarter, we consider four or five other things. The first is that the Q4 comp result was a plus one. And if we will look back further, we've obviously been experiencing negative comp trends for sometime with the fourth quarter being the first positive in a long time. The second is that February is a small month and it's impacted by Valentine's Day. We believe that the environment continues to be challenging and unpredictable. We're managing the business very conservatively and to be more specific about that, inventories at the end of the year was down 9% per foot and that can put some pressure on sales based on that conservative inventory position or at their lowest level in five years. With that said, we're working very hard to aggressively chase winters. And then lastly, we intend to be, and Diane and Sharen can comment on this more specifically, but we intend to be less promotional in the first quarter than we were a year ago and that's going to put some pressure on the comp as well.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stuart. And now maybe to add some comments about strength in February, I want to go to Diane first.
componenttext: Thanks, Stuart. And now maybe to add some comments about strength in February, I want to go to Diane first.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really, I think in February, it really started out on our big three categories. As you know, we relaunched, restaged our Anti-bac business and that is getting very positive response from our customers, as well as the fact that we restaged Signature last y
componenttext: Really, I think in February, it really started out on our big three categories. As you know, we relaunched, restaged our Anti-bac business and that is getting very positive response from our customers, as well as the fact that we restaged Signature last year. I'm concerned about how big that was anniversary. We actually had two fragrance launches in February this year versus none last year. So that has also been received very favorably from our customers. And then also, we have additional fragrance launches in home fragrance, as well as a much broader candle fragrance assortment this year in February than we had last year. All three of those really driving our results.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is Sharen. For Victoria's Secret, as you know, we own Valentine's Day. And so this year as we went into Valentine's Day, we had stronger assortments. We actually had the ability to test into color and then we act into color for the month of Febru
componenttext: Hi, this is Sharen. For Victoria's Secret, as you know, we own Valentine's Day. And so this year as we went into Valentine's Day, we had stronger assortments. We actually had the ability to test into color and then we act into color for the month of February, so that goes to what we're trying to do with speed and agility. We have the right product very focused and had more depth behind our key items as we went in to February. We often have a strong bra launch coming into February as well as the new lace of bra. As we think about going forward into first quarter, we have made a commitment to really be regular priced. And as we all know last year, we drove a lot of the business group promotion, so we're being very conservative and continuing to keep the flexibility and staying close to our customer.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Stein from Soleil Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Stein from Soleil Securities.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Stuart, back last fall when you held your Analyst Day, you indicated that to get to that 15% EBIT margin, you needed kind of a low to mid-single digit comp over the next several years. So if you're guiding to kind of a flat to up slightly this year, I'm w
componenttext: Stuart, back last fall when you held your Analyst Day, you indicated that to get to that 15% EBIT margin, you needed kind of a low to mid-single digit comp over the next several years. So if you're guiding to kind of a flat to up slightly this year, I'm wondering, is there another path possibly to that 15% EBIT margin if, in fact, comps don't materialize as you expect?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of thoughts on that. The first is, we're not expecting a particularly good environment in 2010. And at some point, between now and 2012, hopefully the environmental will get a little bit better so that we have a little color on the comp for 2010.
componenttext: A couple of thoughts on that. The first is, we're not expecting a particularly good environment in 2010. And at some point, between now and 2012, hopefully the environmental will get a little bit better so that we have a little color on the comp for 2010. With that said and answer to your question, there are additional things that we can do to improve the operating margin in the business and this all involve trade-offs and risks. But obviously, to the extent that we don't realize the sales growth that's inherent in our plan, we'll intensify our review of expenses and the trade-offs and risks that would run with a more aggressive view of expense reductions. As you know, we've taken a lot of expenses out of the business. We think we managed expenses well in '09 and have a good plan for 2010. But to the extent that we don't achieve our sales goals, we'll look at the other big levers in the P&L to try to get to that result.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Barbara Wyckoff from Jesup & Lamont.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Barbara Wyckoff from Jesup & Lamont.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I have a question about the new system. Sharen, could you elaborate on the new systems, specifically what they would do for you in Victoria's Secret. And I guess, Diane, could you give us some examples of what these systems have done for Bath & Bo
componenttext: I guess I have a question about the new system. Sharen, could you elaborate on the new systems, specifically what they would do for you in Victoria's Secret. And I guess, Diane, could you give us some examples of what these systems have done for Bath & Body?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, we implemented our new system back in the summer. And as we think about really optimizing these systems is that it gives us the capability to really get demand signals quicker, to be able to have more concised inventory in the right places at
componenttext: As you know, we implemented our new system back in the summer. And as we think about really optimizing these systems is that it gives us the capability to really get demand signals quicker, to be able to have more concised inventory in the right places at the right time. Obviously, it will take us a while to build up, to truly get the total effect of the system and that is something that we're working through. We're excited about the opportunity but yet, we're just now putting our toe in the water in terms of optimizing.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as far as the benefit for Bath & Body Works, I think we saw a very large benefit in the fourth quarter. Because we looked at balance of inventory by store because as you know, it's a full model [ph] versus a push model [ph] so respond to what the cust
componenttext: And as far as the benefit for Bath & Body Works, I think we saw a very large benefit in the fourth quarter. Because we looked at balance of inventory by store because as you know, it's a full model [ph] versus a push model [ph] so respond to what the customer is responding to. So inventories and our in-stock by decile are basically pretty even whether it's a top line store or a lower volume store, depending on the market. And so, our balance gives us some of the higher seasonal items that we typically are taking a lot of markdowns, we actually sold it, it's really regular price and had very little going into our semi-annual sale in January.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Morris from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Morris from Bank of America.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question for Diane and Sharen. You talked a little bit about it in some of your prepared remarks so I would like to have you guys go a little bit deeper, give us a little bit more color as you look ahead on spring. Where do you see the opportunit
componenttext: I have a question for Diane and Sharen. You talked a little bit about it in some of your prepared remarks so I would like to have you guys go a little bit deeper, give us a little bit more color as you look ahead on spring. Where do you see the opportunity in the merchandise assortment compared to last year? Sharen, you talked about, for example, correcting some mistakes and making some improvements. But I'm thinking specifically in terms of the Merch Assortment categories in addition to your remarks already on inventory.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, as we think about our spring assortments, the first thing was last year, we had the wrong colors. We did not have the flexibility to react. As we implemented the new systems, we had to pull all the inventory forward so we did not have the op
componenttext: First of all, as we think about our spring assortments, the first thing was last year, we had the wrong colors. We did not have the flexibility to react. As we implemented the new systems, we had to pull all the inventory forward so we did not have the opportunity to react to the mid-set [ph] in color. So what's going to be different this spring? First of all, we have clean inventories. We've tested the colors and assortments not only the Bra categories and the Panty categories but also in the Sleepwear category, as well as Beauty. Last year, we have a lot less flexibility. This year, we have open to buy and agility. Last year, we were highly promotional. This year, we have the confidence in the assortments because we have tested and reacted to that, that we will be less promotional. We have less distractions in the business and we were launching and instituting a new system, as well as pulling back expenses. So then when we think about the assortments that we have, we know that we have strong bra launches coming forward because we have tested them. The other piece is we have strong bras that we launched in the fall season like the miraculous bras that we see still has the opportunity and more like in the spring season by continuing to innovate on that bra and coming back with a sustained relaunched program. We have really been focusing in the Panty category on key items that can kind of multiply, like we did in lacing, taking that into cotton. We had to focus about panties that match back and we've done a much better job this season that has panties that are exact match back and has easier navigation. We think our sleepwear assortments, we've tightened up and focused and narrowed that assortment which now we can go back in selling coolness in [ph] outfits back to the Bra and Panty category. So I think -- as well as with Pink, we've continued to see momentum in that business. So I think all in all, as to how we're positioning the business for the spring season, although internally we have a lot of optimism, we're very cautious. We remained very close to the customer in order to test, read and react with agility. If you think about it in terms of the months [ph] that we have is to execute with simplicity, discipline and speed. And I think that we're seeing that work, that we really started in the first half of last year, pay off for us.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Diane, opportunity to last year?
componenttext: Diane, opportunity to last year?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: When I look at our business, it's really just continuing what's already strong. We've learned a lot this past year by simplifying our focus on our big three categories. And we look forward into spring season, we basically had two big fragrance launches la
componenttext: When I look at our business, it's really just continuing what's already strong. We've learned a lot this past year by simplifying our focus on our big three categories. And we look forward into spring season, we basically had two big fragrance launches last year and similar to this year we have six. Anti-bacterial restaged last year. We did not do very many fragrance launches. We have significant amount of different collection of fragrance launches in the Anti-bac business with spring, as well as some old-fashioned type opportunities in our Hand Sanitizer categories. And in home fragrance, we really are getting a whole assortment kind of consistent across the fleet. So this year, it's about offering two different fragrance, Stanley, Brassiere [ph] was basically about half a one so that's significantly up to last year, as well as building on innovation in our [indiscernible] category which we really didn't have last year.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just love some updates on some of the smaller projects that have been going on in smaller brands around. If you can just talk a little bit about whom you bundles, you've opened a few stores but I don't see any for 2010. I don't see any Pink standa
componenttext: I would just love some updates on some of the smaller projects that have been going on in smaller brands around. If you can just talk a little bit about whom you bundles, you've opened a few stores but I don't see any for 2010. I don't see any Pink standalones really in the U.S., is this just a Canadian concept at this point? I was curious what you guys were doing with CO Bigelow. Have you made any decisions about that as well? If you could just touch on that. And then if you would remind as what the plan number of the Travel &  Tourism stores were for 2010?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to [indiscernible] a little bit. We'll go to Martyn first with Bendel and Travel & Tourism.
componenttext: I'm going to [indiscernible] a little bit. We'll go to Martyn first with Bendel and Travel & Tourism.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the update on the number of things, I probably can just tick through in terms of the status of the CO Bigelow concept, we have reduced the number of stores in the pilot for that concept to around three. It is three. And we're continuing to work on
componenttext: I think the update on the number of things, I probably can just tick through in terms of the status of the CO Bigelow concept, we have reduced the number of stores in the pilot for that concept to around three. It is three. And we're continuing to work on the positioning of that concept. On the Henri Bendel concept, we have now 10 stores opened and we're very encouraged actually by the early  results of those 10 stores. They had a fabulous holiday and a fabulous result, both through the Fifth Avenue store and the concept stores. We consider it to be a very important pilot of a new concept. And while we're showing on the new store opening schedule that we're not planning to open more stores in 2010, we're very focused on reading that pilot, positioning it for profitability and growth in the future. But we think we've got the right number of stores up and running right now to kind of work it, and Les is very engaged personally in that concept.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was just curious if this is strictly going to be a Canadian standalone concept now, or is there plans to open up Pink standalones in the U.S. eventually?
componenttext: I was just curious if this is strictly going to be a Canadian standalone concept now, or is there plans to open up Pink standalones in the U.S. eventually?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marni, we have our highest share. We have 10 free-standing Pink stores today in the United States. And in fact, we're opening up our Soho stores, which opens up next week, which is we're very excited about. We continued to learn from these free-standing P
componenttext: Marni, we have our highest share. We have 10 free-standing Pink stores today in the United States. And in fact, we're opening up our Soho stores, which opens up next week, which is we're very excited about. We continued to learn from these free-standing Pink stores, so we're continuing to mind for opportunities with free-standing Pink stores as well in the U.S.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Canadian front, we have four opened and we're planning to open another five in 2010. So we're continuing to focus on the Pink free-standing store concept in Canada, particularly in its positioning as a brand relative to our La Senza brand. And as y
componenttext: On the Canadian front, we have four opened and we're planning to open another five in 2010. So we're continuing to focus on the Pink free-standing store concept in Canada, particularly in its positioning as a brand relative to our La Senza brand. And as you heard in my remarks, we're also opening the four Victoria's Secret stores this year in Canada. So that will be a continuation of introducing those brands to Canada and also validating our capability to do so in terms of delivering our brands to a foreign country. The last question you have was T&T and as of the end of the year, we have seven stores now open. Since the update call, we've opened another shop in Mexico City and one in Singapore. Again, those early pilot stores continue to exceed our expectations. We're very optimistic about the sales productivity, but we're also very focused on getting the assortment and the merchandising right because it is a new concept. It's not something that we really have done before. So again, we're pretty cautious about expanding that. We did say we're targeting to open another 10 to 15 stores in 2010.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America, Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America, Merrill Lynch.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: With Canada such a crucial geography for you going forward, I was just hoping to get a more detailed update on La Senza on what strategies in the revamp of that brand are working and what's not working? And then, how will you position the new Victoria's S
componenttext: With Canada such a crucial geography for you going forward, I was just hoping to get a more detailed update on La Senza on what strategies in the revamp of that brand are working and what's not working? And then, how will you position the new Victoria's Secret stores versus La Senza in Canada?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lorraine. We'll go to Martyn.
componenttext: Thanks, Lorraine. We'll go to Martyn.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mentioned in my remarks, we're very focused on the La Senza business as one of our core brands now. We formed a very strong partnership with between Martin Waters, our Head of our International, Joanne Nemeroff, the Head of the La Senza business in Cana
componenttext: I mentioned in my remarks, we're very focused on the La Senza business as one of our core brands now. We formed a very strong partnership with between Martin Waters, our Head of our International, Joanne Nemeroff, the Head of the La Senza business in Canada and her team. And they have been working diligently on testing and learning about the different positioning, brand positioning, the store positioning, store design and construction options that would allow us to even further strengthen the positioning of that brand, create what we call a clear blue water of brand positioning between the VS brand and the La Senza brand in Canada as we introduce VS. And really, get that brand positioned as another one of our core brands that we then could reposition internationally, potentially even bring into the United States.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Howard Tubin from RBC Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Howard Tubin from RBC Capital.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question for Sharen, can you talk about the Pink brand in its entirety for a second and do you see continued opportunities to grow that further?
componenttext: Question for Sharen, can you talk about the Pink brand in its entirety for a second and do you see continued opportunities to grow that further?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: We do see a lot of opportunity to grow the Pink franchise today. A couple of things is that one of the things that Pink has really not been in is in the Bra business so that is truly a focus for us as we think about Victoria's Secret and Pink being best a
componenttext: We do see a lot of opportunity to grow the Pink franchise today. A couple of things is that one of the things that Pink has really not been in is in the Bra business so that is truly a focus for us as we think about Victoria's Secret and Pink being best at bras. There are lots of opportunity to grow the Bra business. As you know, we have a partnership with the colleges in terms of what we call CLI program and that continues to be strong in a different shade of pro-Pink[ph]. But we continue to looked at opportunities within the Pink franchise, continue to see more and more growth coming from Pink as we expanded the Bra category, continue to maximize the CLI. And then at the core of Pink is the [indiscernible] program and we continue to see that Apparel business being strong.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Black from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Black from Barclays Capital.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: For Martyn, we talked about the store strategy for international and in Canada and in the airport. When might we see a licensing phase? Sort of what's the footprint looks like in your mind three years out? And then just an add-on for Stuart, can you just
componenttext: For Martyn, we talked about the store strategy for international and in Canada and in the airport. When might we see a licensing phase? Sort of what's the footprint looks like in your mind three years out? And then just an add-on for Stuart, can you just give us some color on how math might impact the gross margin across the first half given the benefit we saw last ?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. We'll start with Martyn.
componenttext: Thanks, Jeff. We'll start with Martyn.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the international strategy, yes, you know we gave a very full update at the Update Meeting in October. And Martin Waters I think presented what we call a six-point agenda and strategy. And just to reiterate because it does impact how we think
componenttext: In terms of the international strategy, yes, you know we gave a very full update at the Update Meeting in October. And Martin Waters I think presented what we call a six-point agenda and strategy. And just to reiterate because it does impact how we think about the next steps, our core focus in the international front is for the La Senza brand and its positioning and growth in Canada and beyond. The new businesses that we're introducing to Canada, BBW in Canada, Pink and VS in Canada, the rollout pilot test and rollout of this Travel & Tourism concept. And then yes, the franchising model, in other words, than what we discussed in the October meeting, was to begin with the franchising model focused on Bath & Body Works. And while we're not in a position really to announce anything specific today on that front, I would say that we've made a lot of progress, that we're on track to meet the goal that to we discussed in the Update Meeting of announcing something this year.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Martyn. And Stuart on math?
componenttext: Thanks, Martyn. And Stuart on math?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: It doesn't have a material affect in terms of mixed shift in the first half. So as we've had to step down some sales related to Express and Limited stores, the last over 12 or 18 months, we've had an effect which we've talked about but that's essentially
componenttext: It doesn't have a material affect in terms of mixed shift in the first half. So as we've had to step down some sales related to Express and Limited stores, the last over 12 or 18 months, we've had an effect which we've talked about but that's essentially leveled off and there's not a significant margin impact.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Janet Kloppenburg from JJK Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Janet Kloppenburg from JJK Research.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions first on the February comp, I know you're talking about being less promotional, but I was wondering how the promotional cases was at each brand during February, higher or lower versus last year? And also for Sharen, I was wonde
componenttext: I had a couple of questions first on the February comp, I know you're talking about being less promotional, but I was wondering how the promotional cases was at each brand during February, higher or lower versus last year? And also for Sharen, I was wondering how you felt about the inventory levels on your best sellers right now, the Miraculous Bra, the lacy panty program, will they be able to carry you through to meet the strong demand going forward, let's say in March and April? And for Diane, if you could talk specifically about when the Anti-bac business begin to ramp and from the influence of the swine flu scare and how you'll counter that as you go up against those what we might call extraordinary comparisons?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we'll start with Sharen. Start Sharen, two pieces, promotional levels in February and then inventory.
componenttext: So we'll start with Sharen. Start Sharen, two pieces, promotional levels in February and then inventory.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we actually, we're not promotional, any pricing promotions we did not do in the month of February. We did do a surprise in July in terms of our partnership with Godiva. With this, Godiva candy which was personalized during Valentine's but if you're tal
componenttext: So we actually, we're not promotional, any pricing promotions we did not do in the month of February. We did do a surprise in July in terms of our partnership with Godiva. With this, Godiva candy which was personalized during Valentine's but if you're talking about any true pricing promotions or red lines or clearance, none of that happened in the month of February.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what about last year, Sharen?
componenttext: And what about last year, Sharen?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: We did take some pricing action last year. We anniversaried where we took a T-shirt brand [ph] between 950 so there were some promotions that we did anniversary from last year.
componenttext: We did take some pricing action last year. We anniversaried where we took a T-shirt brand [ph] between 950 so there were some promotions that we did anniversary from last year.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you had a more profitable month as well in terms of margin?
componenttext: So you had a more profitable month as well in terms of margin?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are looking an improvement in margin in February, that is correct. When you think about some of our key items such as the Miraculous, yes, although we did chase in the 400,000 units in holiday, we did come into February a little light in Miraculous. We
componenttext: We are looking an improvement in margin in February, that is correct. When you think about some of our key items such as the Miraculous, yes, although we did chase in the 400,000 units in holiday, we did come into February a little light in Miraculous. We are now back in stock in Miraculous and we have really strategically work with our sourcing and manufacturing partners that we have a constant delivery flow to meet the customer demand. As well as the lacy, we're in very good position right now with the lacy and it's something that we're continuing to monitor. And really, really focused on how to stay in stock in those top items but if we get down and missed a little bit of business because of how we're flowing, we're going to stay cautious about our inventories to maximize it. And if we missed a little bit of business, that's okay because we'd rather miss a little bit than be too long in inventory.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the first question on Bath & Body Works I think is about promotional levels.
componenttext: And the first question on Bath & Body Works I think is about promotional levels.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: In February, specifically.
componenttext: In February, specifically.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And basically, we're down to last year to say[ph]. In fact, we have a lot less clearance. Last year, we were clearing our old Signature Collection which we are up against so we have less clearance on last year. And then as far as the swine flu, it really
componenttext: And basically, we're down to last year to say[ph]. In fact, we have a lot less clearance. Last year, we were clearing our old Signature Collection which we are up against so we have less clearance on last year. And then as far as the swine flu, it really hit us when our business really took off and specifically, as to sort of around the Hand Sanitizer category was in April. And what we've done to offset that is we have fragrance launches happening in March and April in the Anti-bac category, in Home category of kitchen order elimination in the anti-bac, as well as the fact we have a fragrance launch to summer vanillas in Signature in April which we do not have any fragrance launches in Signature last year.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Todd Slater from Lazard Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Todd Slater from Lazard Capital Markets.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've made some really good progress on the operating margin front hitting about a 10% rate, but still well below your past peaks obviously. But how heroic do we need the economy to be to hit your 2010 guidance because it doesn't seem like you need much
componenttext: You've made some really good progress on the operating margin front hitting about a 10% rate, but still well below your past peaks obviously. But how heroic do we need the economy to be to hit your 2010 guidance because it doesn't seem like you need much of a tailwind. I'm just curious what your assumptions are in terms of the external environment? And it doesn't also sound like there's any assumptions that you're baking in for the huge royalty income opportunity just begging to be monetized for this whole franchised venture. It sounds like you're still not considering anything on that front.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: So with respect to your questions, with respect to an assumption about the environment in 2010, that's underlying our views. We're not assuming any significant improvement in the environment. We're assuming an environment that continues along the lines th
componenttext: So with respect to your questions, with respect to an assumption about the environment in 2010, that's underlying our views. We're not assuming any significant improvement in the environment. We're assuming an environment that continues along the lines that we're experiencing today. And with respect to anti-bac international in 2010, with respect to franchising or licensing, we don't have any material amounts in the 2010 numbers with respect to that.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brian Tunick from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brian Tunick from JPMorgan.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Stuart, sort of two questions for you. First, if you could help us maybe understand the profitability in the other segment, Bath & Body Works Canada versus may I sort of where are the operating margins between those two businesses? And then the s
componenttext: I guess, Stuart, sort of two questions for you. First, if you could help us maybe understand the profitability in the other segment, Bath & Body Works Canada versus may I sort of where are the operating margins between those two businesses? And then the second question on Victoria's Secret Direct, it sounds like most retailers think that the Online or Direct business is 800 to 1,000 basis points better than their Store business. It doesn't sound like Vicky Direct is high versus the stores. Is there any inherent reason why that can't be higher?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me try to take those questions, Brian. With respect to kind of profit rates within the other segment, the Bath & Body Works Canada business, as you would expect, is a higher profit rate business than the mass business. If you thought about mass and th
componenttext: Let me try to take those questions, Brian. With respect to kind of profit rates within the other segment, the Bath & Body Works Canada business, as you would expect, is a higher profit rate business than the mass business. If you thought about mass and thought about others in that business that you're familiar with, we're familiar with Li & Fung, our margin structure is similar to that kind of business. There's not a lot of capital in these businesses and that sets the operating margin rates lower. With respect to the Bath & Body Canada business, while it's not yet at its ultimate potential in terms of margin rate, it would be more analogous to well-performing bricks and mortar of business. With respect to your question about the operating margin levels in Direct versus Stores, the Direct business is more profitable today on a rate basis than the Store business, but I think you're question is further wise and even more profitable. That's in part because Direct bears marketing expense associated with the catalog that obviously drives revenue for the Direct business, but also a benefit of the overall brand. So that would be, to me, the other factor that really consider within with respect to the relative profitability of Direct and Stores. So to be specific, Direct bears the full cost of the catalog marketing for the brand.

componenttext: Miraculous has been so successful, what do you see as the drivers of that launch? And applying it to others, how can what you learned from Miraculous help other launch to be more successful? And on Bath & Body Works, what do you see as the opportunities to drive sales and margins in 2010? Is it more price, or is it product in terms of sales and margins?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: One of Victoria's Secret skill set is the fact the new launches all have fundamentals of what we do. And although Miraculous was very successful, and we're proud of it, it's not our most successful bra launch ever. And one of the things that we do is ever
componenttext: One of Victoria's Secret skill set is the fact the new launches all have fundamentals of what we do. And although Miraculous was very successful, and we're proud of it, it's not our most successful bra launch ever. And one of the things that we do is every time we launched a bra, we actually go out, we pull it forward, we test it, we learn from it, we listen to the customer and we apply all of that rigor around every launch that we do. And I think that as one of the fundamentals is when you launches, also what has to go with that is new merchant flow to pass and react. And I think therefore, that combination of the power on power did drive the sales in process. But, we always can keep getting better and better.

componenttext: Stuart, can you comment on transactions in 2010 or maybe the branch fed. Do you think you have that figured out? Would you expect transactions to be positive in 2010? componenttextpreview: In terms of how we are thinking about the transactions today for the spring season, we really expect the transactions to be flat. As you know last year, we were highly promotional. This year, we wanted to do more of that. Get a price business and that is
componenttext: In terms of how we are thinking about the transactions today for the spring season, we really expect the transactions to be flat. As you know last year, we were highly promotional. This year, we wanted to do more of that. Get a price business and that is our strategy. We look at traffic pricing a little flat to down as well, so we expect conversions to be up. And we have put a lot in place in terms of the new selling strategies within the stores and the store expectations, which we started to see the results of driving that conversions in holiday. So the combination of the new selling models in the store execution plus with the assortments and the launches, we do believe that we will see conversion up. I think that from an AUR perspective, we'll probably see the AUR slightly up and cost are pretty much flat to last year.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Three or four things, Stacy, on expenses. The first is we had our goals in '09 so we set some pretty aggressive goals in '09. And the second thing I would reiterate and it's not new perspective, it's just a continuation reinforcement of it which is that w
componenttext: Three or four things, Stacy, on expenses. The first is we had our goals in '09 so we set some pretty aggressive goals in '09. And the second thing I would reiterate and it's not new perspective, it's just a continuation reinforcement of it which is that we're actually committed to expenses growing slower than sales and to leveraging those expenses. It's an important component over the past of 15% and we, as a management team, we're very committed to that. And then lastly probably two more points, we will continue to pursue [indiscernible] expense management in 2010, nothing major to describe other than ongoing discipline there as an overall point. And then plus in some earlier Q&A, if we don't get the sales growth that we're all working very hard to do and we're very confident that based on the power of these brands we can realize, we'll re-evaluate the opportunities for a more significant expense actions that may be possible recognizing that those put them to trade-offs and risks.

componenttext: My question is more for Sharen but Diane as well. As you guys continue to see strong full price selling and moving to speed to market initiatives and continue on a lean inventory path, have you considered any adjustments to the semi-annual sale events where you have to produce product for those events? Any comment on that would be great.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are constantly looking at the semi-annual sales. And every year, we actually took a few days off and just semi-annual sale in [indiscernible]in January. And as we continue to look at the inventories, the only thing that would keep us to have any level
componenttext: We are constantly looking at the semi-annual sales. And every year, we actually took a few days off and just semi-annual sale in [indiscernible]in January. And as we continue to look at the inventories, the only thing that would keep us to have any level higher than last year is that we're exiting a big block of them. So we are going to stick with the strategy that we started in the fall season about keeping red lines off the floor. So therefore, we're going to keep clean inventories on the floor so that we will still continue to either be flat or down, even though we're not going to be selling red lines during the season.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: At Bath & Body Works, demand in sales was down pretty significantly in January. We're also planning it significantly fewer days in June just based on how we have planned our business. But we typically buy into semi-annual sales anyways, we have our classi
componenttext: At Bath & Body Works, demand in sales was down pretty significantly in January. We're also planning it significantly fewer days in June just based on how we have planned our business. But we typically buy into semi-annual sales anyways, we have our classic fragrances that we carry around online that we buy back into for semi-annual sales, as well as hair products that we don't carry in our stores year around. It kind of offer as a service to our customers.
