headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you look at our big three categories, our Signature, Anti-bacterial Soap business and Home Fragrance, we still have, I think, upside and long-term growth for those categories with not only new fragrance introductions, but we have got gr
componenttext: Well, I think when you look at our big three categories, our Signature, Anti-bacterial Soap business and Home Fragrance, we still have, I think, upside and long-term growth for those categories with not only new fragrance introductions, but we have got great response to all the new formula upgrades that we have had. We've got more formula upgrades coming in the fall season as well as a whole new fashion assortment in some of our Home Fragrance areas. So we feel actually the three categories themselves offer continue off of that growth.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sharen?
componenttext: Sharen?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Todd, I'll take the technology question first, then I'll get into the opportunity. We are very pleased with the implementation that we did last year and it went very smoothly. And we installed a new platform with really minimal distraction to the busin
componenttext: So Todd, I'll take the technology question first, then I'll get into the opportunity. We are very pleased with the implementation that we did last year and it went very smoothly. And we installed a new platform with really minimal distraction to the business, which was our goal. And we are seeing the benefit, and I think those benefits will grow over time. But also, I'd just want to remind us, all of us, that the systems are an enabler but they don't determine performance, and the merchandise decisions and retail executions do. And we believe our focus and discipline in those areas really are yielding the results that we need. When I think about the opportunity at Victoria's Secret, is that we have really increased our seat to market in the spring season, really allowing us to keep open to buy and flexibility in reading and reacting and making big bigger. And I think that we're just at the beginning of our speed initiative, which I think will only enhance our performance, not only from a sales perspective but also from a profit perspective. The other thing, in terms of how we deliver fashion and actually this year, we will be adding a whole new fashion delivery in the month of June. That is very key. And then the last point I would make is that as we think about our key bra launches, is that this year, we have had a better balance between our bra launches and giving true incrementality of the bra launches, and doing more than one thing at a time to really capture a broader customer. And so we're very pleased with that but still have much more to do around that key initiative.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from Janet Kloppenberg of JJK Research.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if Sharen and Diane would address any sourcing pressures that they're looking at in the back half of 2010 and into 2011, and if that could result in some higher pricing going forward?
componenttext: I was wondering if Sharen and Diane would address any sourcing pressures that they're looking at in the back half of 2010 and into 2011, and if that could result in some higher pricing going forward?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Sharen. I think that you may be referring to anything from a cotton, when you keep reading about cotton prices going up. We were very aggressive in really identifying that with our sourcing partners, and it really took a position. So I think in the b
componenttext: It's Sharen. I think that you may be referring to anything from a cotton, when you keep reading about cotton prices going up. We were very aggressive in really identifying that with our sourcing partners, and it really took a position. So I think in the back half, you will not see any increases in our prices. What that means for 2011 is yet to be seen. But right now, we do not see any significant increase in pricing in our sourcing. And I think that we are very well positioned and that's really through our great partnerships that we have.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: But Sharen, will that allow you to maintain the value equation you now have in place and perhaps the customers looking for more value because your promotional activity is declining?
componenttext: But Sharen, will that allow you to maintain the value equation you now have in place and perhaps the customers looking for more value because your promotional activity is declining?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It will allow us to keep our same value, absolutely. Our promotional activity is absolutely -- we have not had any promotional activity in terms of sales or anything that's in the first quarter. And I think, that what we have every day is a great value pr
componenttext: It will allow us to keep our same value, absolutely. Our promotional activity is absolutely -- we have not had any promotional activity in terms of sales or anything that's in the first quarter. And I think, that what we have every day is a great value proposition in terms of the quality of our product, the fact that we instituted a good-better-best pricing strategy as we entered into 2010, and that's working very well for us. And we see nothing that is going to get in our way to be able to continue to deliver on that.

componenttextpreview: The Naked launch exceeded our expectation and we were very pleased with the Naked launch. The other thing that we were pleased with the Naked launch is that because it's an unlined bra, we not only did well with the Naked launch, at the same time, we also
componenttext: The Naked launch exceeded our expectation and we were very pleased with the Naked launch. The other thing that we were pleased with the Naked launch is that because it's an unlined bra, we not only did well with the Naked launch, at the same time, we also saw increment in terms of our push-up category. So we were very pleased with the performance. We have a very strong lineup of launches coming forward at not only at the back half of the second quarter but also as we go into the fall season.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Stein of Soleil Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Stein of Soleil Securities.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question for Stuart. Stuart, it sounds to me like a lot of the improvements that you guys have made in terms of EBIT margin so far has come from better execution. So I'm wondering if you could just kind of talk about the flow-through in each of your core
componenttext: Question for Stuart. Stuart, it sounds to me like a lot of the improvements that you guys have made in terms of EBIT margin so far has come from better execution. So I'm wondering if you could just kind of talk about the flow-through in each of your core businesses and how that has changed. In other words, a dollar of incremental sales flow through at x cents on a dollar, one, two years ago, now it flows through at y. What would that relationship be today versus a couple of years ago?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe the way to overview that is when the business -- and I'm going to be plain spoken and simplistic about it, but I think it makes the main point. When our business is not doing well in some combination from the economy and our own execution and our co
componenttext: Maybe the way to overview that is when the business -- and I'm going to be plain spoken and simplistic about it, but I think it makes the main point. When our business is not doing well in some combination from the economy and our own execution and our comps are negative, the flow-through on sales chain is going to be pretty significant in terms of how that looks. A normal flow-through in the business would be in terms of a dollar of increased sales. Normally, we'd see $0.30 to $0.40 of operating income flow through. What we've had in the fourth quarter, particularly, and this first quarter is we've had extraordinary flow-through. And particularly, in this first quarter, we had sales growth, obviously. We had very substantial merchandise margin rate improvement, and then we got leverage on the buying occupancy line and on the expense line as we continued to manage expenses pretty well. But this flow-through is extraordinary, and the product of a lot of good hard work. And over time, as we lap better results, we'll get to that more normal flow-through of 30% to 40%. And again, that's to the operating income line.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So would you characterize the first quarter flow-through rate is probably a rate that would not be sustainable?
componenttext: So would you characterize the first quarter flow-through rate is probably a rate that would not be sustainable?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Now when I say extraordinary, I mean extraordinary. I frankly, in my time in this business and in some others, I've never seen flow-throughs quite like this before in a very positive sense. And again, the product of everybody on this call and
componenttext: Absolutely. Now when I say extraordinary, I mean extraordinary. I frankly, in my time in this business and in some others, I've never seen flow-throughs quite like this before in a very positive sense. And again, the product of everybody on this call and lots of other people working really hard to drive a good top line, to do all the things we're doing to improve merchandise margins and also managing expenses in a tough-minded disciplined way.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jennifer Black of Jennifer Black & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jennifer Black of Jennifer Black & Associates.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is for Sharen. I wondered if you could talk about VSX and shapewear? And are you making any changes to your catalog circulation?
componenttext: My question is for Sharen. I wondered if you could talk about VSX and shapewear? And are you making any changes to your catalog circulation?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We launched the shapewear category this spring season in a pretty full-blown way in about 50 stores to get a test read, and we were very pleased, and really have been reacting with speed to be able to actually put that product in even more stores. So what
componenttext: We launched the shapewear category this spring season in a pretty full-blown way in about 50 stores to get a test read, and we were very pleased, and really have been reacting with speed to be able to actually put that product in even more stores. So what that test allowed us to do is really test broad. Now we focused into the real winners, and we are going to continue to expand that as we go into the fall season. So we're very excited about that. Our VSX business right now is comping about 42% in the stores that it was in this year versus last year. So we still feel good about this category. And I think, that as we think about our continued disciplined focus on the bra and panty category through 2010, hopefully, we'll see even more opportunity in VSX as we go through 2011. Catalog circulation, there is no change. And in fact, we're actually going to be publishing a new exclusive Pink catalog, this back-to-school time frame. But the catalog circulation is not changing.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Morris of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Morris of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Diane and Sharen, as you each look ahead to fall and holiday, where do you see the opportunity in the merchandise assortment to last year? Can you give us a couple of specific highlights of where that opportunity might be? And Martin, on La Senza, is it p
componenttext: Diane and Sharen, as you each look ahead to fall and holiday, where do you see the opportunity in the merchandise assortment to last year? Can you give us a couple of specific highlights of where that opportunity might be? And Martin, on La Senza, is it possible to bring that brand to the U.S. at some point? And if so, when could that be?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll start with Diane.
componenttext: We'll start with Diane.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, John, I probably can't give you some specifics on what we've got going forward in the fall and holiday season for many reasons. But we have in our big three key categories, we continue to have more newness than last year and continue to learn this s
componenttext: Well, John, I probably can't give you some specifics on what we've got going forward in the fall and holiday season for many reasons. But we have in our big three key categories, we continue to have more newness than last year and continue to learn this spring season. And as Sharen has mentioned, we are also working on the speed model so this learnings that we have now, we're implementing into the third and fourth quarter for this year.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we think, about fall and holiday, number one, we are excited about where we're headed from a product launch, compared to last year as we have that in working progress, right, as we speak. When I think about Q3, we will have no sale. Last year, in Septe
componenttext: As we think, about fall and holiday, number one, we are excited about where we're headed from a product launch, compared to last year as we have that in working progress, right, as we speak. When I think about Q3, we will have no sale. Last year, in September, we had a big sale. We're looking at being full priced. We're looking at turning faster, we're looking at continuing a focus on the bra and panty category. We're looking at to continue the leverage of bringing the brand story to life into the store, so that as we continue to drive traffic, get better execution, also continue to hopefully to see the record conversion. We will be entering the third quarter, balancing the conservatism with optimism, as we're getting very good traction in the business today with the macro economics being what they are. We want to keep as much agility as we can, so that we can read and react. And I think, that we're getting paid for those results by being conservative in the first quarter, and we will continue that same thinking and discipline, as we go into the third and fourth quarter. But we are very excited about the products.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sharen. Martyn?
componenttext: Thanks, Sharen. Martyn?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, On La Senza, I think, a couple of key messages are really, the first thing to come to mind to me, is -- so you've seen in my remarks, we're making a lot of changes with our La Senza management team, our La Senza business, our La Senza brand. So the
componenttext: John, On La Senza, I think, a couple of key messages are really, the first thing to come to mind to me, is -- so you've seen in my remarks, we're making a lot of changes with our La Senza management team, our La Senza business, our La Senza brand. So the first key message is the changes we're making are indicative of the fact that we're declaring that La Senza is a core brand to us on a worldwide basis. Our first priority is Canada and the positioning of the brand and the assortment in Canada, and managing our way through the transitions that we're making with management team. Our second priority for La Senza is to reposition the international franchise system for La Senza, which you may recall, is 400 stores distributed through 40 countries around the world. And the management team is very focused on how to reengage with our international franchisees in a very positive and growth-oriented way. Beyond that, all kinds of things are possible, but we don't have any current plans or timelines attached to other ideas.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kimberly Greenberger of Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kimberly Greenberger of Citi.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Sharen, if you could update us on our speed initiative. I think, you had mentioned a goal of getting 40% to 50% of the key items of Victoria's Secret onto a six-week reorder or lead time? Where are you in that process? And ultimately, how
componenttext: I was wondering, Sharen, if you could update us on our speed initiative. I think, you had mentioned a goal of getting 40% to 50% of the key items of Victoria's Secret onto a six-week reorder or lead time? Where are you in that process? And ultimately, how fast you think you can get in terms of the core everyday product at Victoria's Secret?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, Kim, we are continuing to work to get better, and we have reduced our lead times about 50%. Today, we do have a robust basics program, which were constantly flowing good. And as I mentioned in my opening remarks is that, within the speed initia
componenttext: Right now, Kim, we are continuing to work to get better, and we have reduced our lead times about 50%. Today, we do have a robust basics program, which were constantly flowing good. And as I mentioned in my opening remarks is that, within the speed initiative, we make great progress. And I don't want to take anything away from the progress. But we're at the beginning of the beginning. And I think, that there's a lot more for us to do in terms of how -- the basic piece is easy, because that's just the constant flow of reorder in and out and get it through the distribution center and our inventory availability in stores have gone up. Where we even want to get faster is in our ability around the fashion. As you know, fashion is where you have -- where you take your biggest risk. And I think, that the ability for us now to have tested all the fall  colors already and have a great indicator of what colors are working, and then being able to read and react to those and get those in within eight weeks. And I think, there's even more opportunity to continue to compress the lead time. So we're at the beginning of the beginning of the journey. We're learning a lot. And we're going to continue to challenge ourselves to even get faster.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Barbara Wyckoff with Jessup Lamont (sic) [Jessup & Lamont].
componenttext: Your next question comes from Barbara Wyckoff with Jessup Lamont (sic) [Jessup & Lamont].

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question for Sharen and for Diane. Sharen, with the success of the Naked collection and the Pink bras, how do you see the opportunity for this younger layer -- to add this younger layer to your core product mix? And then for Diane, with all the f
componenttext: I have a question for Sharen and for Diane. Sharen, with the success of the Naked collection and the Pink bras, how do you see the opportunity for this younger layer -- to add this younger layer to your core product mix? And then for Diane, with all the focus on the three categories, other businesses have been, like aromatherapy and Bigelow have been lacking in innovation and newness. Do you have any plans to tweak these categories as well?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Barbara, it's Sharen. It's that we've been very pleased with our Pink assortment and the reaction that we've been getting. We also believe that the total Victoria's Secret positioning has gotten younger. We have now just recently launched Pout, which we d
componenttext: Barbara, it's Sharen. It's that we've been very pleased with our Pink assortment and the reaction that we've been getting. We also believe that the total Victoria's Secret positioning has gotten younger. We have now just recently launched Pout, which we do believe is actually a different kind of fit, it's really comes off of Victoria and we changed that to the name, Pout, so it really fits in between Pink and the kind of the core bras of where we are. So I think between Pink, between Pout, and then just the general assortment becoming younger in Victoria's Secret, we're well positioned for every young customer.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Barbara, as far as Bath & Body Works, tweaked is probably the right word. We continue to add newness to things like aromatherapy and Bigelow. And in fact, we're restaging the entire lip category in Bigelow in the summer, which is the majority of the B
componenttext: And Barbara, as far as Bath & Body Works, tweaked is probably the right word. We continue to add newness to things like aromatherapy and Bigelow. And in fact, we're restaging the entire lip category in Bigelow in the summer, which is the majority of the Bigelow business for us. So we are adding newness to these categories, but certainly not the same kind of focus as the big three.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on your second quarter comp guidance of two to four, implying a notable slowdown versus up 10 in the first quarter, despite easier compares. Just wondering if there's anything you're seeing out there, or is it just a degree of conservatism. And t
componenttext: Question on your second quarter comp guidance of two to four, implying a notable slowdown versus up 10 in the first quarter, despite easier compares. Just wondering if there's anything you're seeing out there, or is it just a degree of conservatism. And then Sharen, if you can just give us the hit to the second quarter comp from the shorter VS semi-annual sale?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we're going to go to Stuart for that.
componenttext: So we're going to go to Stuart for that.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So with respect to our comp guidance for the second quarter, just to reiterate three or four points that most on our mind, the first is that we are lapping significant promotion from last year. And as mentioned already through the call, we intend to be mu
componenttext: So with respect to our comp guidance for the second quarter, just to reiterate three or four points that most on our mind, the first is that we are lapping significant promotion from last year. And as mentioned already through the call, we intend to be much less promotional in Q2. Then the last thing I would say, is we continue to manage this business very conservatively and with discipline. And so those are really the key messages around how we see comps for Q2. Much less promotional, managing with conservatism and discipline.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Michelle, actually the Victoria's Secret semiannual sale is not shorter. It is online.
componenttext: And then Michelle, actually the Victoria's Secret semiannual sale is not shorter. It is online.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Victoria's Secret Direct is being shortened by five days. And honestly, I honestly believe that because we've pulled back on all the promotions that we will have created some pent-up demand. And I believe that we will be flat to last year, even shorte
componenttext: The Victoria's Secret Direct is being shortened by five days. And honestly, I honestly believe that because we've pulled back on all the promotions that we will have created some pent-up demand. And I believe that we will be flat to last year, even shortening the sale.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Dana Telsey of Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Dana Telsey of Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lately, top line stability improvements certainly has been the trend. How is the AUR trending and how do you see it moving forward, given the speed in fashion that's involved in both businesses? And just lastly, you've had good successful launches at Vict
componenttext: Lately, top line stability improvements certainly has been the trend. How is the AUR trending and how do you see it moving forward, given the speed in fashion that's involved in both businesses? And just lastly, you've had good successful launches at Victoria's Secret, whether it's Miraculous, whether it's the Naked. What's being done differently to get these types of results than perhaps in the past?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Sharen. I can take the first one. Our AUR is basically flat, as we continue to balance the mix of the business, balance the good-better-best pricing. So we have great growth between the balance, between units and AUR. So we're very pleased with that.
componenttext: It's Sharen. I can take the first one. Our AUR is basically flat, as we continue to balance the mix of the business, balance the good-better-best pricing. So we have great growth between the balance, between units and AUR. So we're very pleased with that. When I think about what we're doing differently from a launch perspective, is that we have been able to unlock how to get more incrementality from the total business as we go into launch. So the fact that we are bringing in bras -- the Miraculous is two cup sizes, and so what we're seeing is that bringing in that bra also lifts Very Sexy. Why would it lift Very Sexy push-ups? Because if someone doesn't want that kind of lift, they still have a great option in push-up. The same thing with Naked, it's a lightly lined bra. So we're adding diversity within the assortment that helps us to continue to get more incrementality to the total business.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Dana, AUR at Bath & Body Works is down slightly than last year, but that is mainly due to mix. As we have more of our business done in our top three categories, the AURs are lower than, as we look at our performance brands, or even the third-party bra
componenttext: And Dana, AUR at Bath & Body Works is down slightly than last year, but that is mainly due to mix. As we have more of our business done in our top three categories, the AURs are lower than, as we look at our performance brands, or even the third-party branded business that we exited last year, but our EDS [ph] is up slightly as a result.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Erika Maschmeyer of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Erika Maschmeyer of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've done a great job of paying down debt. What's your goal or endgame here? Can you remind us of your philosophy? And then also, could you update on inventory turns by brand? And then you think you're in for Bath & Body Works versus Victoria's Secret.
componenttext: You've done a great job of paying down debt. What's your goal or endgame here? Can you remind us of your philosophy? And then also, could you update on inventory turns by brand? And then you think you're in for Bath & Body Works versus Victoria's Secret. I know you've recognized substantial benefit, particularly at Bath & Body in terms of lowering inventory and increasing in stocks.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Stuart for both of those.
componenttext: We'll go to Stuart for both of those.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So with respect to debt and our philosophy on capital structure, the first thing I would say is we're very comfortable with our level of balance sheet debt and our total debt. As we commented on, we have reduced it about $400 million over the last six mon
componenttext: So with respect to debt and our philosophy on capital structure, the first thing I would say is we're very comfortable with our level of balance sheet debt and our total debt. As we commented on, we have reduced it about $400 million over the last six months or so. And we're not seeking, per se, an investment grade rating. What's important to us is that we have appropriate cash and liquidity, which we do. That we have flexibility, which we do. This business generates a lot of cash flow. We're comfortable with our balance sheet debt. The maturity profile, we've improved a lot over the last 18 months or so. So it's a very good maturity profile. We're very comfortable with our capital structure situation. With respect to inventory turns, we're not going to go into the details of that by business. But what I can tell you is that we have been improving, turning all of our major businesses over the last 12 to 18 months. It's a key focus for us, but we're not going to go into the details of that by brand.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Howard Tubin of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Howard Tubin of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe one question for you, Martyn. Can you update us on your plans and thoughts for the Victoria's Secret business outside of North America?
componenttext: Maybe one question for you, Martyn. Can you update us on your plans and thoughts for the Victoria's Secret business outside of North America?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. As I mentioned in my remarks, Howard, we are planning to open our first Victoria's Secret full flagship stores in Canada in the late summer timeframe, four stores in Canada. That really is the test and validation for us, of our ability to deliver th
componenttext: Sure. As I mentioned in my remarks, Howard, we are planning to open our first Victoria's Secret full flagship stores in Canada in the late summer timeframe, four stores in Canada. That really is the test and validation for us, of our ability to deliver the Victoria's Secret full flagship, full store brand to a foreign country. And that's the next major step in our development of Victoria's Secret outside of the United States. Beyond that, we have not announced any specific plans. And I think, as we did with BBW, we used Canada as our test batter. For BBW it started that process a couple of years ago. Now as we move forward, we'll be looking for opportunities on a worldwide basis for Victoria's Secret, but taking a very cautious and careful approach. The other thing we are continuing to work on is the T&T concept or what we call T&T, which is travel and tourism, which is under the Victoria's Secret brand name. But as we described  on previous calls, is a hybrid, accessories, beauty and limited intimate apparel assortment, distributed through airport retail locations, as well as a couple of department store, shop-in-shop kind of locations, and we're continuing to see very positive results from that piloted learning experience and looking to continue to expand that in the balance of the year.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Neely Tamminga of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Neely Tamminga of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Diane, I just have a question for you. You've had project insight, I think, longer than the VS division. And I'm just wondering how some of the toolbox to read and react. Sharen often talks about I think, is a good step in the right direction, what you gu
componenttext: Diane, I just have a question for you. You've had project insight, I think, longer than the VS division. And I'm just wondering how some of the toolbox to read and react. Sharen often talks about I think, is a good step in the right direction, what you guys have been able to already affect and do and what's the potential path can be for VS on the road to using those tools?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not quite sure the insight tools is what really gets you in the read and react and the speed model. It's more about the head set of the organization and us testing and learning from that agenda. And it's really about the actions and discipline a
componenttext: Well, I'm not quite sure the insight tools is what really gets you in the read and react and the speed model. It's more about the head set of the organization and us testing and learning from that agenda. And it's really about the actions and discipline and execution that we have versus really, using a systems tool.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Marni Shapiro of The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Marni Shapiro of The Retail Tracker.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sharen, I saw Pout and I thought it looks great. And I was curious more about Pink, how it fits in next to Pink. Will you really keep it as a separate agenda, different on the floor? And then also in Pink, you've done a very good job of taking some of the
componenttext: Sharen, I saw Pout and I thought it looks great. And I was curious more about Pink, how it fits in next to Pink. Will you really keep it as a separate agenda, different on the floor? And then also in Pink, you've done a very good job of taking some of the promotions from Victoria's Secret, the two-for bras, the mix-and-match tees and tanks and bringing them to Pink, but you've continued to overlay that with the free flip-flops and things to that affect. Can you just talk about how you plan to strategize going forward, because it seems like you pulled some parts from Victoria to Pink, but kept the Pink stuff there?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't pull anything Victoria's Secret into Pink. So I think, that what we're looking at from a Pink perspective and that positioning, it is really targeting to that 19-year-old collegiate girl. So then, it can also go down in age as well. And so when
componenttext: We didn't pull anything Victoria's Secret into Pink. So I think, that what we're looking at from a Pink perspective and that positioning, it is really targeting to that 19-year-old collegiate girl. So then, it can also go down in age as well. And so when we think about the two for $32 is that you have to buy two bras that come together. It's almost, if you think about it as your first bra. In terms of Pout, it's a totally different positioning than Pink. It's really a lifestyle, it's more European in feeling. And it has a different fit aesthetic than what Pink has.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And will you continue to layer on the two-for promotions and keep the original Pink ones, like the flip-flops?
componenttext: And will you continue to layer on the two-for promotions and keep the original Pink ones, like the flip-flops?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, that if you're talking about the GWP, it's really a total Pink, and it's really a surprise and delight. So then when you think about wanting a piece of the Pink brand, we give away, to come in and make a purchase and get a free dog. So we h
componenttext: Well, I think, that if you're talking about the GWP, it's really a total Pink, and it's really a surprise and delight. So then when you think about wanting a piece of the Pink brand, we give away, to come in and make a purchase and get a free dog. So we have pulled those things in and out as really as a surprise and delight, and we will continue to do that.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Black of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Black of Barclays Capital.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question for Stuart and just how you're running the business here. And I know, you said you were very promotional last year. But does the guidance really say anything about what you're seeing with the traffic now first. Second, do you think you have the
componenttext: A question for Stuart and just how you're running the business here. And I know, you said you were very promotional last year. But does the guidance really say anything about what you're seeing with the traffic now first. Second, do you think you have the ability to chase into trends if you see some better sales trends as we saw in 1Q with comps, well North of what you guided to? And third, as we look at the back half, is there anything, or I guess what would change your thinking on how you inventory the business and what might move you to a more aggressive posture this year, if at all?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a lot wrapped up in that question. But the four or five points that I would make aren't just from my perspective, it's the perspective of the teams running the business, is there is some uncertainty in the environment. But you shouldn't inte
componenttext: Well, there's a lot wrapped up in that question. But the four or five points that I would make aren't just from my perspective, it's the perspective of the teams running the business, is there is some uncertainty in the environment. But you shouldn't interpret our guidance as some new view of that. As we commented on, we remain comfortable with our May comp guidance of flat to low single digit, will be a point to reiterate. Another point to reiterate is again, affecting those numbers is doing a lot less promotion this year than we did a year ago. And maybe two more points. We continue to manage this business in a conservative way. It's really paid dividends for us over the last 18 to 24 months. We talked earlier in this call about flow-through. You get that great flow-through when you manage the business conservatively and looping back to a part of your question, we are able to chase goods. Both Sharen and Diane have commented previously, and again today, about their focus, along with the sourcing part of the organization and working with our sourcing partners about continuing to work hard to reduce lead times and have more agility, have more open to buy and that absolutely allows us to read and react and chase in shorter periods of time. And we certainly have done that through the fall of last year and again, this quarter. So I think, those are our key headsets, if you will, of points of view as it relates to the sales line and things around that for the balance of the year.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're last question comes from Roxanne Meyer of UBS.
componenttext: You're last question comes from Roxanne Meyer of UBS.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is relating to about Victoria's Secret Direct. How do you see the opportunity to grow the business, I guess, in part, keeping in mind how far apparel have come versus last year? What categories are currently under-penetrated on online. And whe
componenttext: My question is relating to about Victoria's Secret Direct. How do you see the opportunity to grow the business, I guess, in part, keeping in mind how far apparel have come versus last year? What categories are currently under-penetrated on online. And when do you think you will begin to grow Victoria's Secret Direct internationally, knowing that it does take time to build up that infrastructure, but perhaps that might be the best opportunity?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, there's a couple of categories that we are under-penetrated in. The two, which are our priorities right now online are Pink, as well as Beauty. So those are the two big categories that we're under-penetrated on, that tied back to the brand that w
componenttext: I think, there's a couple of categories that we are under-penetrated in. The two, which are our priorities right now online are Pink, as well as Beauty. So those are the two big categories that we're under-penetrated on, that tied back to the brand that we have big opportunity. As I told you earlier, we are starting a Pink catalog as we go into the fall season. Today in the Direct business, we do about $200 million internationally, without really doing anything different. We do believe that there is an international opportunity. But as the team really is looking at all of our international strategy, the Direct piece will be part of that. So there will be looking forward to more news on that subject later.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We thank all of you for joining us this morning, and we thank you for your continuing interest in Limited Brands. Thanks.
componenttext: We thank all of you for joining us this morning, and we thank you for your continuing interest in Limited Brands. Thanks.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010

componenttext: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Stephanie and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Limited Brands second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any backgroun
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Stephanie and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Limited Brands second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers’ remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. (Operator instructions) Amie Preston, Vice President of Investor Relations. You may begin your conference.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Limited Brands’ second quarter earnings conference call for the period ending Saturday, July 31, 2010.As a matter of formality, I need to remind you that any forward-looking statements we may make today are s
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Limited Brands’ second quarter earnings conference call for the period ending Saturday, July 31, 2010.
As a matter of formality, I need to remind you that any forward-looking statements we may make today are subject to our Safe Harbor statement found in our SEC filings. Our second quarter earnings release and related financial information, including any non-GAAP or adjusted financial reconciliation tables, are available on our Web site, limitedbrands.com. This call is being taped and can be replayed by dialing 1-866-NEWS-LTD. You can also listen to an audio replay from our Web site.
Martyn Redgrave, EVP and Chief Administrative Officer; Stuart Burgdoerfer, EVP and CFO; Sharen Turney, CEO of Victoria’s Secrets; and Diane Neil, CEO of Bath & Body Works are all joining us today. After our prepared comments, we will be available to take your questions for as long as time permits. So that we can speak with as many callers as possible, it’s important that you limit yourself to one question.
Thanks. Now I’ll turn the call over to Martyn.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Amie, and good morning, everyone. I’d like to start by saying that we continue to be very pleased with our performance and the progress that we’ve made so far this year.In the second quarter, our comps increased 7% and our operating income i
componenttext:
Thanks, Amie, and good morning, everyone. I’d like to start by saying that we continue to be very pleased with our performance and the progress that we’ve made so far this year.
In the second quarter, our comps increased 7% and our operating income increased by nearly 60%. Our adjusted earnings per share of $0.36 exceeded our initial expectations of $0.27 to $0.32 and nearly doubled last year’s $0.19 result. By the way, this is a record result for the company.
This very strong performance was the result of our intense focus on execution, staying close to our customers, and increasing speed and agility. We continue to believe that the environment remains uncertain and challenging.
Accordingly, as Stuart will explain in more detail, we have and will continue to manage inventory expenses and capital very conservatively. We also continue to drive the business with an overriding focus on our disciplined execution of retail fundamentals.
Improving our ability to react with speed and agility to maximize our sales and profit opportunities yielded results throughout the first half of this year and continues to be a critical priority.
Our entire organization is aligned and focused on these key priorities. While we’ve made considerable progress, we see more opportunities to improve in many areas. Our number one priority continues to be improving the results of our core US businesses. Our operating income rate increased significantly in the second quarter and this gives us confidence that we are on track towards our 15% operating income rate goal.
We also were enthusiastic about the opportunity for the growth of our businesses outside the United States. So before I turn it over to Stuart, I’d like to provide you with an update on our international businesses beginning with the La Senza business.
On last quarter’s call, I discussed various actions that we’re taking to improve the results of La Senza, including closing the underperforming Girl business, improving product assortment and store experiences, and moving the creative and merchant teams from Montreal to Columbus, Ohio.
We accomplished the move in the past month, and our new Columbus-based team is made up of a great core of key leaders and associates who relocated to Montreal and a complementary group of team members from other parts of Limited Brands and the retail industry.
Now, it will take some time for the benefits for these changes to be realized, including the benefit of the new team, and to have an impact on the business. We are already beginning to see some results from intensifying our focus on bras and panties and our store remodel tests, and we are confident that we will continue to see improvement.
In the second quarter, La Senza comps were flat and sales were $101.8 million, and the merchandise margin rate increased significantly. As a result of the costs of approximately $3 million related to the relocation of the business, La Senza’s operating income was down to last year.
Now, turning to out other businesses in Canada, we ended the quarter with 39 Bath & Body Works stores and six Pink stores. We continue to be very pleased with the performance of these stores. Last week we opened our first Victoria’s Secret store outside of the United States in the West Edmonton Mall in Alberta, and we are very encouraged by the early results.
We will open three more Victoria’s Secret stores over the next few months in the Yorkdale, Eatontown center, and Square One malls, all in the Toronto market. In addition, we plan to open two more Pink stores and about 20 more Bath & Body Works stores across Canada in the fall season.
We also announced that we secured a location for our Victoria’s Secret London flagship store which is expected to open in 2012. The store will be located at the prestigious corner of New Bond and Brook streets, which is a world-class location. Finally, we’re on track to open our first BBW franchise locations this fall in the Middle East under our partnership with the Alshaya Group.
So with our expansion plans in Canada and the early success we’re seeing in other initiatives, we believe we are just beginning to exploit the full potential of our brands internationally. In closing, we’re very pleased with the progress and performance of the business over the last few quarters, and we continue to see opportunity to improve in all parts of our business and we are focused on getting even better.
Thanks, and now I’ll turn it over to Stuart.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Martyn, and good morning everyone. Turning to our second quarter performance, our adjusted earnings per share increased to $0.36 a share from $0.19 last year. Our reported results were $0.54 per share this year versus $0.23 last year. As detailed
componenttext:
Thanks, Martyn, and good morning everyone. Turning to our second quarter performance, our adjusted earnings per share increased to $0.36 a share from $0.19 last year. Our reported results were $0.54 per share this year versus $0.23 last year. As detailed in our press release, both years’ reported results include significant items as follows:
For this year, we had a pre-tax gain of $52.3 million or $0.10 per share related to the sale of a portion of our shares of Express in its initial public offering. We had a pre-tax gain of $19.7 million and a related net tax benefit of $22.4 million or $0.13 per share in total related to the sale of our remaining interest in related to the sale of our remaining interest in Limited Stores and had a pre-tax loss of $25.2 million or $0.05 per share associated with the early retirement of 400 million of our 2012 and 2014 bond.
As you will recall, in the first quarter we issued $400 million and 10-year bonds and in May we used proceeds to repurchase our earliest maturities.
These three items net to a benefit of $0.18 per share. The 2009 results includes the benefit totaling $0.04 per share related to a pre-tax gain of $9.4 million and a related tax benefit of $4.6 million from the divestiture of a non-core joint venture. Our results discussed on this call exclude these significant items.
So to take you through the second quarter results in more detail, net sales were $2.243 billion versus $2.067 billion last year and cost increased 7%. The gross margin rate increased 230 basis points to 34.7% driven by a significant increase in the merchandise margin rate.
Buying and occupancy expense increased slightly as a percent of sales. SG&A expense increased by $21.7 million or 4% and the SG&A rate leveraged by 100 basis points. The expense increase was driven by an increase in store selling costs and marketing expense.
Total operating income increased $87.8 million or 340 basis points as a percent of sales to $236.5 million or 10.5% of sales.
By segment, the Victoria’s Secret segment increased by $65.3 million or 360 basis points as a percent of sales to $191.7 million or 13.2% of sales. Bath & Body was increased by $20.3 million or 370 basis points as a percent of sales to $64.4 million or 12% of sales.
In the other segment, operating loss declined by $2.3 million to $19.6 million. Total non-operating expenses decreased by $19.8 million, driven by an increase in equity income from Express and Limited Stores during the quarter and a decrease in interest expense.
Turning to the balance sheet, retail inventories ended the quarter down 5% per foot at cost.
Turning to our earnings outlook for the remainder of the year, two things are impacting our results versus our previous guidance. First, our sale of Express shares in their IPO decreased our ownership to about 18%. As we noted in last quarter’s call, because our ownership percentage fell to below 20%, we were evaluating whether to continue to account for our ownership in Express under the equity methods or whether we should move to available for sale accounting.
Based on certain events in the second and third quarters, including the resignation of our Board seats in early August, we determined that available for sale accounting is appropriate going forward.
Additionally, we sold our remaining interest in Limited Stores in the second quarter for $32 million. The change in accounting for Express investment and the sale of our Limited Stores investment will have the following impact on our business.
First, we will no longer record equity income from Express or Limited Stores in other income.
Second, massed sales to Express and Limited Stores will now be recognized at 100%. This increase to sales will negatively impact our gross margin rate and positively impact our SG&A rate, but will not significantly impact our operating income rate.
Additionally, we have increased our estimated tax rate to 39.5% versus 38% previously. The impact of all these changes decreased our third quarter earnings forecast by approximately $0.02 per share and the full-year forecast by approximately $0.08 per share.
So, turning to the third quarter, we are forecasting earnings per share between $0.03 and $0.08. This forecast reflects a comp increase of 3% to 5%. Our comp estimate for the quarter includes an updated view for August comps in the mid-to-high single-digit range versus our earlier guidance of low-single digits.
We expect to see other segment sales growth of between $60 million and $70 million, driven by the previously mentioned change in accounting for Mast sales and growth in our international business. We expect the gross margin rate to be up to last year and the SG&A rate to be roughly flat. We expect total non-operating expense of approximately $45 million consisting principally of interest expense.
Before any discrete items, our tax rate will be approximately 39.5% and weighted average shares will approximate $330 million in the third quarter. We expect that inventory per foot through the third quarter will be flat to up slightly. We continue to manage inventories conservatively and with discipline.
For the full year, we are projecting a mid-single digit comp increase. We expect sales growth in the other segment between $210 million and $225 million. Full-year gross margins will be up to last year, and we expect the full-year SG&A expense rate to improve versus last year.
We expect full year interest expense of about $210 million, down over $25 million from last year as a result of our reduction in debt in 2009 and the repayment of our term loan this year. We are projecting total other income, including interest income, of roughly $30 million.
Assuming all of these inputs, we expect earnings per share for the full-year 2010 to be between $1.68 and $1.83 per share. Adjusting for the $0.08 decrease from the impact of the Express accounting change, the sale of our remaining interest in Limited Stores, and our increased tax rate we’ve increased the midpoint of our full-year guidance by $0.13 to $0.14 versus our previous guidance.
We are projecting 2010 CapEx of $250 million to $300 million with roughly 70% of this spending on real estate and stores. Consistent with our prior view we plan to open roughly 45 stores this year, mostly in Canada, and close roughly 70 stores. We’ll end the year with total square footage roughly flat to last year.
The details of our 2010 store plans are included in the supplemental financial information package on our Web site. Our remaining CapEx spending relates to technology, distribution centers, and home office projects.
Turning to liquidity, we expect free cash flow in 2010 to be between $550 million and $650 million. Our free cash flow or cash position along with the additional availability under our revolving credit facility results in very strong liquidity, which is more than sufficient to fund our working capital, capital expenditures, dividends, and any other foreseeable needs. We repurchased 2.7 million shares for $66.3 million in the second quarter under our $200 million share repurchase program.
Thanks and now I’ll turn the discussion over to Sharen.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stuart, and good morning, everyone. We continue to be pleased with the recent progress made in Victoria’s Secret. Last quarter I discussed how we have been purposefully managing our business with a balance between optimism and conservative ma
componenttext:
Thank you, Stuart, and good morning, everyone. We continue to be pleased with the recent progress made in Victoria’s Secret. Last quarter I discussed how we have been purposefully managing our business with a balance between optimism and conservative management at inventory and expenses.
I also told you that our focus would continue to be on our core categories, bras and panties, coupled with an emphasis on speed and agility. As with Q1, these priorities together with a well told story across channels helped us delivery must-have fresh assortments for our customers. We did this with leaner inventories relative to sales and consequently drove improved financial performance. In addition, we once again achieved record conversion rate in our stores in the quarter.
Now let’s move to a review by channel. In Victoria’s Secret stores, our comps for the quarter were up 13% with total sales increasing 14% to $955 million. Our results were driven by improvements in all three business units
Lingerie, Pink, and Beauty.
In Lingerie, customers responded to the constant newness and fashion we are providing through the Miraculous Bra; the improved Body by Victoria Collection, including lace; cotton bras and improved cotton panties; the Lacie Panty; Swim; and the Nakeds collection.
Customers also loved the additional floorset we introduced before semiannual sale, helping to drive our regular price sales up double-digit over last year during sale. Pink also continued to deliver strong performance.
Our new initiative to grow the bra business in Pink has exceeded our expectations. Apparel offerings in Pink such as the heritage, graphics, and yoga, continue to remain strong as well, and we continue to see success in our collegiate and pro licensing assortments.
The Beauty business also exceeded our expectations with solid growth across key categories, driven by our base business and added freshness with multiple new seasonal product introductions.
The second quarter gross margin rate was up significantly to last year, primarily driven by an increase in the merchandised margin rates. The newness and strength of our assortment and well-managed inventory contributed to increased full price selling, while we decreased promotional activity. Operating income dollars and rates were both up significantly to last year in the stores channel.
Now, let’s review performance at Direct. Second quarter sales increased 9% to $391 million drive by broad-based strength across the assortments, especially Lingerie, Pink, Swim, Dresses and Active.
The gross margin rate increased significantly, driven by a significant increase in the merchandised margin rate as the strength of the assortments enabled us to reduce promotional activity. Additionally, SG&A expense leveraged, so operating income dollars and rate were up significantly to last year at Victoria’s Secret Direct.
Looking ahead to the third quarter, we will continue the discipline that served us well in the spring season. First, we will continue to drive product innovation and newness with emphasis on speed and agility. In addition, we will continue to monitor our inventories closely, utilizing read and react strategy. Above all, we will continue our efforts to get even closer to our customers, enabling us to drive ongoing improvements in the customer experience and our financial performance.
So, thank you, and now I will turn it over to Diane.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sharen, and good morning. At Bath & Body Works, we are very pleased with the results of the second quarter. We were able to deliver significant operating income growth versus last year while being significantly less promotional.We continue to
componenttext:
Thank you, Sharen, and good morning. At Bath & Body Works, we are very pleased with the results of the second quarter. We were able to deliver significant operating income growth versus last year while being significantly less promotional.
We continue to deliver improved results versus last year by maintaining focus on our three key categories, our Signature Collection product lines, the antibacterial soap and sanitizer business, and our home fragrance assortment.
Performance in our Signature Collection was driven by the re-launch of our Body Lotion in a new and improved formula, the launch of new fragrances like Forever Sunshine, and the restage of our men’s line.
The antibacterial business continued its strong performance, driven by both our self-enhanced sanitizer categories, including the launch of new fragrance collections like Tropical Temptations and Fresh Nectar.
Our home fragrance sales were up to last year and continued to be driven by very strong candle performance, as well as the introduction of new forms in our diffuser category.
So, with that backdrop, let me take you through the financial results for the quarter, Bath & Body Works’ second quarter comps were flat. The disciplined management of our inventory allows to shorten our semi-annual sale by 10 days versus last year, which is important for the positioning of our brand over the long term, we estimate the shorter sale negatively impacted the second quarter comps by three to five points, despite growing profit in the second quarter.
Total sales for the quarter were $536 million, which was up 1% or $3 million versus last year.
For the quarter, our operating income was $64 million, which is up $20 million or 46% to the second quarter of last year. Operating income as a percentage of sales was 12% in the quarter and up significantly to last year. Operating income was driven by improvements in merchandise margin rates and expense decreases. Our SG&A expense leveraged in the second quarter.
We also finished the quarter with inventory levels down to last year. This is our 13th consecutive quarter with inventories down year-over-year, while our in-stock positions continue to improve.
The Bath & Body Works’ Direct channel delivered strong sales growth, and we continue to view the direct channel as both a revenue generator and marketing vehicle for our brand.
So with that in mind, in the third quarter, we will continue to introduce newness and innovation in both form and in fragrances. In late July, we began our annual Great American Hand Soap event, which will run until late August. We followed that with a launch of Dark Kiss, which is our newest signature collection fragrance.
We’re cautiously optimistic about the third quarter and we will continue to manage expenses and inventory conservatively. We’re excited about our assortment and the visual feel of our stores.
In addition to our focus on product and fragrance launches, we will continue to test and read the results of new product offerings and promotional strategies maintaining flexibility in our inventory, so that we can react quickly to our customers’ needs.
So with that, I’ll turn the discussion back over to Amie.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010

componenttext: Great, thanks and congratulations on a terrific quarter. It seems like you’ve got a huge opportunity at some point down the road for international DTC, but obviously, you have to optimize a DUS [ph] business platform, and I know it’s lower on your priority list of international. I’m just wondering what plans do you have in the US with your DTC platform to make it more seamless with retail as it relates to both the customer interaction as well as one big deal of inventory. Thank you.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010

componenttext: Thanks, Roxanne. Sharen is going to take that question.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, Roxanne. We have an initiative to actually make our DTC and stores really looking at it from a loyal customer view that it can be seamless. We will be testing some of these initiatives like returns in stores, purchasing in-store online if you don’t
componenttext: Hi, Roxanne. We have an initiative to actually make our DTC and stores really looking at it from a loyal customer view that it can be seamless. We will be testing some of these initiatives like returns in stores, purchasing in-store online if you don’t have the stock in the stores this fall season. So we do have a roadmap and we are just starting that journey and very optimistic about the opportunity that it will allow us to have for the company.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe, Martyn, do you want to talk about the international?
componenttext: And then maybe, Martyn, do you want to talk about the international?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think on the international front you’ve got it deducted right, Roxanne. We’ve said consciously, it’s not our number one priority. We have a very full plate agenda on the international front for Martin Waters and his management team. You’re
componenttext:
Yes, I think on the international front you’ve got it deducted right, Roxanne. We’ve said consciously, it’s not our number one priority. We have a very full plate agenda on the international front for Martin Waters and his management team. You’re also right to say that there is a big opportunity there. We are doing some groundwork internationally in terms of Web site language capabilities and other preparations to improve our ability to do business with our international customers.
Again, it remains lower on our agenda until we kind of get some of these cross channel and other capabilities in place in the United States. On the other hand, it does represent a very nice piece of business for us, probably $125 million to $175 million kind of business outside the United States for us today.

componenttextpreview: Thanks and congrats as well. I guess for Martyn or Stuart, just a little clarity on sourcing. Clearly you guys have a different mix than most of your peers, but how do you see any cost inflation as we move through the year and into next year, and just can
componenttext: Thanks and congrats as well. I guess for Martyn or Stuart, just a little clarity on sourcing. Clearly you guys have a different mix than most of your peers, but how do you see any cost inflation as we move through the year and into next year, and just can you discuss how Mast would be impacted?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. Good morning and thanks for your kind words on a quarter. With respect to sourcing, I think as most know that follow our company, our number one priority is around quality and speed and getting the right product at the right time available fo
componenttext:
Sure, Brian. Good morning and thanks for your kind words on a quarter. With respect to sourcing, I think as most know that follow our company, our number one priority is around quality and speed and getting the right product at the right time available for sale to our customers. That is the most important thing in our business related to sourcing. Lot of discussion about cotton in China and transportation and so on, it’s important to remember that a lot of our business is personal care and beauty, which is principally sourced in the United States.
With that said, there are some pressures in the environment. We don’t see a significant impact in 2010 and we’re going to work hard to minimize that impact in 2011 as well, but our priorities are really around having great relationships with our suppliers and focusing on quality and speed. We’ve got a great sourcing capability in our business, great logistics capability in our business, and that’s where our focus is.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks, Stuart. Next question.
componenttext: Great, thanks, Stuart. Next question.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. The announcement of the Victoria’s Secret’s flagship in London, I was just curious if this is a signal that you would perhaps roll out VS internationally without a franchise agreement? Also was hoping to get an update on some
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning. The announcement of the Victoria’s Secret’s flagship in London, I was just curious if this is a signal that you would perhaps roll out VS internationally without a franchise agreement? Also was hoping to get an update on some of the other international initiatives like your airport stores?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010

componenttext: Thanks, Lorraine. Martyn is going to take that question.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Morning, again. Yes, I think the way that we have described the London flagship store site is that, our first priority was to identify the right place to start in London, and I think we’ve now done that by securing this site. We’ve also made it clear
componenttext:
Morning, again. Yes, I think the way that we have described the London flagship store site is that, our first priority was to identify the right place to start in London, and I think we’ve now done that by securing this site. We’ve also made it clear that we’ve not made a decision as to how we will operate that London flagship store. It could be a company-owned operation, a franchise operation, or a joint venture operation, as we’ve said consistently, and we have the next 18 months to kind of figure that out.
It obviously does continue to signal our increasing confidence in our ability to take the Victoria’s Secret brand to the rest of the world, and we continue to think that the way to do that is through a combination of company-owned operations, for instance, in Canada for sure and an joint venture and franchise operations probably for the rest of the world. We always reserve the right to think about company-owned operations in certain key geographies as well.
On the T&T, what we call travel and tourism or T&T front, we continue to test and learn about the positioning of that brand, which is a hybrid brand, obviously more beauty and accessories focused, airport oriented, but we also are experimenting with department store, shop within shop, and high street type locations. We’re continuing to be very encouraged by the results, but I think it is because it is a new concept to us.
We’re trying to be very thoughtful about how we position that concept and go get it right before we dramatically expand it. All signals remain positive and we plan to give a much more full update on the travel and tourism concept as well as the other international developments at our Update Meeting in October.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, guys. It’s actually Jennifer [ph] for Todd. My question is on international. Martyn, I know you’d be upset if it wasn’t. Could you talk about how many Bath & Body Works franchises you think that Alshaya will open this year and how many you think
componenttext: Hi, guys. It’s actually Jennifer [ph] for Todd. My question is on international. Martyn, I know you’d be upset if it wasn’t. Could you talk about how many Bath & Body Works franchises you think that Alshaya will open this year and how many you think that they can open in the Middle East? When you think you’ll feel ready to roll out Victoria’s Secret franchises, maybe with Alshaya? And then also, when in 2012, do you expect to open the London Victoria’s Secret store?

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I’ll take a shot at it. Let me start by saying again what we’ve said consistently, our number priority for international development remains Canada. So, not only the repositioning of La Senza in Canada, which we’ll expand or extend into our in
componenttext:
Sure. I’ll take a shot at it. Let me start by saying again what we’ve said consistently, our number priority for international development remains Canada. So, not only the repositioning of La Senza in Canada, which we’ll expand or extend into our international franchise system for La Senza, but also the 50% expansion in the balance of this year of our BBW Canada business, the introduction of four BS stores and another couple of Pink stores, so that remains number one.
Number two, really is this BBW Middle East expansion through the Alshaya Group franchise agreement. We are planning to open six stores by the end of this year with the Alshaya Group. Those are all in process, but why I say the end of this year or the end of the fiscal year, because in the Middle East with the holidays being different we actually will be opening stores in late December, for instance. The travel and tourism concept is next. And then beyond that our ability to expand the Victoria’s Secret brand would come after that.
In terms of the London store, we’re actually working our way through literally the store’s design and construction aspects of that store, we do not have a scheduled opening date at this stage, but probably first half of 2012.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, guys. Congratulations. I was curious if you could just, Victoria’s Secret is obviously on a run and very focused in bras and panties and Pink, but if you can talk about some of the smaller categories within Victoria’s Secret. You guys always seem
componenttext: Hey, guys. Congratulations. I was curious if you could just, Victoria’s Secret is obviously on a run and very focused in bras and panties and Pink, but if you can talk about some of the smaller categories within Victoria’s Secret. You guys always seem to be testing a lot of things. So, just an update on VSX on the color cosmetics you tested Shapewear. And then just anything on sleepwear, as we head into the back half of the year, it becomes more important in the first quarter, so just an update there as well.

headline: Limited Brands Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, Marni. Hope you can hear me okay. In terms of the things that we’ve been testing, Pout actually is rolled into 150 stores for this fall season. So we are excited about the opportunity that we have and the results and we’re just continuing to be co
componenttext:
Hi, Marni. Hope you can hear me okay. In terms of the things that we’ve been testing, Pout actually is rolled into 150 stores for this fall season. So we are excited about the opportunity that we have and the results and we’re just continuing to be conservative about rolling that as we go forward. Shapewear was also a success story for us and we continue to add Shapewear to more of our stores as we go forward in the fall season.
When we think about the sleepwear category and the lift that it brings and the importance that it has to our business in the holiday timeframe, we actually have been testing through our direct channel and our store channel to actually identify the patterns that are winners so that we can actually then read and react, and be more precise with the inventory around these key patterns.
We are excited about the results that we’ve seen so far, although it is still early. So we want to make sure that we continue to balance that optimism with conservatism and make sure we continue to have that flexibility as we get closer to the holiday time to really make big bigger.
In the VSX, we still remain passionate about the VSX category. We’ve gone through some rebranding. In the stores that we have VSX in, the comps are up about 44%, and as we continue to build upon the core and continue to get growth from the core, which will allow us then to take more of an aggressive stand in some of these newer categories.
